Paraconductivity of pseudogapped superconductors

Igor Poboiko 1,2 and Mikhail Feigel’man 3,2 1 Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology, Moscow, Russia 2 National Research University ”Higher School of Economics”, Moscow, Russia 3 L. D. Landau Institute for Theoretical Physics, Chernogolovka, Moscow region, Russia
Abstract

We calculate Aslamazov-Larkin paraconductity σA​L​(T)subscript𝜎𝐴𝐿𝑇\sigma_{AL}(T) for a model of strongly disordered superconductors (dimensions d=2,3𝑑23d=2,3) with a large pseudogap whose magnitude strongly exceeds transition temperature Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}. We show that, within Gaussian approximation over Cooper-pair fluctuations, paraconductivity is just twice larger that the classical AL result at the same ϵ=(T−Tc)/Tcitalic-ϵ𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑇𝑐\epsilon=(T-T_{c})/T_{c}. Upon decreasing ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, Gaussian approximation is violated due to local fluctuations of pairing fields that become relevant at ϵ≤ϵ1≪1italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1much-less-than1\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1}\ll 1. Characteristic scale ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} is much larger than the width ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{2} of the thermodynamical critical region, that is determined via the Ginzburg criterion, ϵ2≈ϵ1dsubscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ1𝑑\epsilon_{2}\approx\epsilon_{1}^{d}. We argue that in the intermediate region ϵ2≤ϵ≤ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{2}\leq\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1} paraconductivity follows the same AL power law, albeit with another (yet unknown) numerical prefactor. At further decrease of the temperature, all kinds of fluctuational corrections become strong at ϵ≤ϵ2italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{2}; in particular, conductivity occurs to be strongly inhomogeneous in real space.

I Introduction

Strongly disordered superconductors near quantum phase transition into an insulator state attract great interest during last years t1 ; t2 ; t3 ; t4 ; e1 ; e2 ; e3 ; e4 ; NP2011 ; SacepeTiN ; Sacepe2009 ; N1 ; Teun1 . On experimental side e1 ; e2 ; e3 ; e4 ; NP2011 ; SacepeTiN ; Sacepe2009 ; N1 ; A1 ; Teun1 , new methods which became available, like low-temperature scanning tunneling spectroscopy which makes it possible to study properties of superconducting state locally with a nanometer-scale resolution. As a result NP2011 ; SacepeTiN an existence of a strong density-of-states (DoS) suppression at temperatures much above the superconducting transition Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} was demonstrated. Such a phenomenon is called pseudogap, in some rough analogy to the phenomenon known for under-doped high-Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} oxide superconductors; however, the origin of pseudogap in usual strongly disordered superconductors like InOx, see Ref. t1, ; t2, , is unrelated to various courses of pseudogap origin, discussed in relation to HTSC. A detailed semi-quantitative theory of superconductivity, starting from BCS-like model with localized single-electron states (near 3D Anderson localization transition) was developed in Ref. t1, ; t2, , elaborating an approach proposed originally in ML and developed numerically in Ghosal .

One of most general phenomenon inherent to disordered superconductors is known to be fluctuational conductivity (paraconductivity) predicted long ago by Aslamazov and Larkin AslamazovLarkin . It is due to appearance of fluctuational (with finite life-time) Cooper pairs at temperatures slightly above Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}. Aslamazov-Larkin (AL) paraconductivity is especially universal in 2D superconductors, where additional conductance per square is

σA​L□=e216​ℏ​TT−Tcsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝐴𝐿□superscript𝑒216Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑇𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐\sigma_{AL}^{\Box}=\frac{e^{2}}{16\hbar}\frac{T}{T-T_{c}}

independently of any microscopic parameters. This result is usually considered to be valid as long as σA​Lsubscript𝜎𝐴𝐿\sigma_{AL} is much smaller than Drude conductance of the metal σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0}, i.e. at ϵ≡T/Tc−1≫Gi=e2/16​ℏ​σ0italic-ϵ𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐1much-greater-thanGisuperscript𝑒216Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝜎0\epsilon\equiv T/T_{c}-1\gg\mathrm{Gi}=e^{2}/16\hbar\sigma_{0}, that is, in the region of Gaussian fluctuations. In bulk systems paraconductivity is less singular, σA​L∝(T−Tc)−1/2proportional-tosubscript𝜎𝐴𝐿superscript𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐12\sigma_{AL}\propto(T-T_{c})^{-1/2}.

More close to the transition point, within fluctuational region ϵ≤Giitalic-ϵGi\epsilon\leq\mathrm{Gi}, interaction between superconducting fluctuations become important and results in the universal scaling behavior of thermodynamics quantities PokrovskiiPatashinskiiBook , that is determined exclusively by space dimensionality and order parameter symmetry. In what concerns kinetic properties (like conductivity) the situation is less clear. Ref. LO2001, provided arguments in favor of the statement that paraconductivity is more sensitive to nonlinear effects and deviates from classical AL form already at ϵ≤Giitalic-ϵGi\epsilon\leq\sqrt{\mathrm{Gi}}, that is, parametrically far from the scaling region. Basically, the arguments of Ref. LO2001, were based upon the suppression of the electron density of states (DoS) due to superconducting fluctuations: reduced DoS leads to suppression of the electron-electron inelastic rate; in turn, that leads to an increase of the order parameter relaxation time τG​Lsubscript𝜏𝐺𝐿\tau_{GL}, with respect to its value known from the Gaussian approximation, τG​L(0)=π​ℏ/8​(T−Tc)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐺𝐿0𝜋Planck-constant-over-2-pi8𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐\tau_{GL}^{(0)}=\pi\hbar/8(T-T_{c}). Since paraconductivity σA​Lsubscript𝜎𝐴𝐿\sigma_{AL} can be generally shown to be proportional to the product T​τG​L𝑇subscript𝜏𝐺𝐿T\tau_{GL}, the above consideration suggests its more singular behavior due to fluctuational suppression of the DoS. However, detailed calculations of the proposed effect were performed LO2001 for the case when strong depairing is present and the whole effect is anyway weak; it remained unclear if indeed temperature behavior of paraconductivity changes qualitatively in the range ϵ≤Giitalic-ϵGi\epsilon\leq\sqrt{\mathrm{Gi}}.

In the present paper we provide an analysis of similar problem from a different perspective. Namely, we consider very strongly disordered superconductor with a well-developed pseudogap ΔPsubscriptΔ𝑃\Delta_{P}. An existence of pseudogap ΔPsubscriptΔ𝑃\Delta_{P} is due to i) localized nature of single-electron eigenstates ψi​(𝒓)subscript𝜓𝑖𝒓\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{r}), and ii) phonon-induced attraction between electrons which leads to formation of localized electron pairs (with opposite spins) populating eigenstates ψi​(𝒓)subscript𝜓𝑖𝒓\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{r}). The energy gain due to formation of such a pair is ΔPsubscriptΔ𝑃\Delta_{P}. Next, hybridization matrix elements Ji​jsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑗J_{ij} provide virtual hopping of electron pairs between different localized eigenstates. If this hopping is sufficiently strong, a superconducting coherent state is formed below some critical temperature Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c};   (for detailed theory of pseudogaped superconductivity see t2 ).

Below we consider the case of ΔPsubscriptΔ𝑃\Delta_{P} that is much larger than Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}, like it was found in InOx thick films studied in Ref.NP2011, . In such a case one may neglect, to a first approximation over Tc/ΔP≪1much-less-thansubscript𝑇𝑐subscriptΔ𝑃1T_{c}/\Delta_{P}\ll 1, the presence of single-electron states: the single-particle DoS will be set to zero. We will show, nevertheless, that the whole qualitative picture of critical fluctuations, including their dynamics, remains the same as for usual disordered superconductors, as long as we stick to the Gaussian fluctuation region. The major difference we found is that now τG​L(0)=π​ℏ/4​(T−Tc)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐺𝐿0𝜋Planck-constant-over-2-pi4𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐\tau_{GL}^{(0)}=\pi\hbar/4(T-T_{c}), i.e. twice larger than the result of the standard theory.

This result is valid as long as thermal fluctuations are weak and their interaction can be neglected. For such a region to exist at ϵ≤1italic-ϵ1\epsilon\leq 1 in a pseudogapped superconductor, a special assumption is necessary; namely, we consider the model with interaction matrix elements Ji​jsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑗J_{ij} possessing large coordination number Z≫1much-greater-than𝑍1Z\gg 1 for the relevant eigenstates which have eigenenergies εi,εjsubscript𝜀𝑖subscript𝜀𝑗\varepsilon_{i},\varepsilon_{j} located within about Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} from Fermi energy. The presence of large parameter Z𝑍Z allows us to derive a dynamical Ginzburg-Landau functional for superconducting fluctuations at T𝑇T near Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} and to calculate paraconductivity at ϵ≥ϵ1≪1italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1much-less-than1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1}\ll 1 where explicit value of ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} depends both on Z𝑍Z and on space dimensionality d𝑑d (we consider d=2,3𝑑23d=2,3 ). At smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon interaction between fluctuations becomes strong enough to affect kinetic coefficient of the Ginzburg-Landau functional, thus the kinetic problem cannot be solved analytically; however, we provide some arguments in favor of the same type power-law singularity in paraconductivity σA​L∝(T−Tc)(d−4)/2proportional-tosubscript𝜎𝐴𝐿superscript𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐𝑑42\sigma_{AL}\propto(T-T_{c})^{(d-4)/2} to exist down to much smaller values of ϵ≥ϵ2italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{2}. Here ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{2} provides a boundary of the region where all thermodynamic fluctuational effects become strong, it is analogous to the Ginzburg parameter in the usual theory of second-order phase transitions; the important point is that ϵ2≪ϵ1much-less-thansubscriptitalic-ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{2}\ll\epsilon_{1} as long as ϵ1≪1much-less-thansubscriptitalic-ϵ11\epsilon_{1}\ll 1.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: in Sec.II we formulate our model based upon Anderson pseudospin  AndersonPseudo representation of the even-only sector of BCS Hamiltonian for localized single-electron states; we provide initial mean-field-like analysis in II.1 and then in Sec.II.2 we develop Popov-Fedotov semionic diagrammatic technique that is convenient to treat long-range and long-time properties of the model near the critical point. Sec. III is devoted to the derivation of the dynamic Ginzburg-Landau functional and to the calculation of the paraconductivity within Gaussian approximation for 2D and 3D systems. In Sec. IV we analyze leading non-Gaussian corrections and estimate characteristic temperature scale ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1}; we find that it scales as Z−1/2superscript𝑍12Z^{-1/2} and Z−2/3superscript𝑍23Z^{-2/3} in 2D and 3D cases, correspondingly; we also analyze the effect of these non-Gaussian corrections upon dependence of σA​Lsubscript𝜎𝐴𝐿\sigma_{AL} on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Then, in Sec.V we consider all other effects beyond the leading Gaussian approximation; these effects are: a) the lack of self-averaging due to strong spatial fluctuations of disorder, and b) infra-red dominated thermal fluctuations of collective modes. We show that corresponding reduced temperature scale ϵ2∝1/Zproportional-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ21𝑍\epsilon_{2}\propto 1/Z in 2D model, and ∝1/Z2proportional-toabsent1superscript𝑍2\propto 1/Z^{2} in 3D; note that it is the same scaling as it is known for the Ginzburg number GiGi\mathrm{Gi} in usual phase transition theory. Sec. VI contains our conclusions. Some technical details are presented in Appendices A, B, C and D.

II The model and diagram technique

The starting point of our approach is representation of the paired electron system in terms of pseudospin operators introduced long ago by P.W.Anderson AndersonPseudo :

Si−=ai↓​ai↑Si+=ai↑†​ai↓†2​Siz=1−ai↑†​ai↑−ai↓†​ai↓formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑎↓𝑖absentsubscript𝑎↑𝑖absentformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑎↑𝑖absent†superscriptsubscript𝑎↓𝑖absent†2superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑧1superscriptsubscript𝑎↑𝑖absent†subscript𝑎↑𝑖absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑎↓𝑖absent†subscript𝑎↓𝑖absentS_{i}^{-}=a_{i\downarrow}a_{i\uparrow}\quad S_{i}^{+}=a_{i\uparrow}^{\dagger}a_{i\downarrow}^{\dagger}\quad 2S_{i}^{z}=1-a_{i\uparrow}^{\dagger}a_{i\uparrow}-a_{i\downarrow}^{\dagger}a_{i\downarrow} (1)

Here operators ai↑subscript𝑎↑𝑖absenta_{i\uparrow} and ai↓subscript𝑎↓𝑖absenta_{i\downarrow}, and, correspondingly, ai↑+superscriptsubscript𝑎↑𝑖absenta_{i\uparrow}^{+} and ai↓+superscriptsubscript𝑎↓𝑖absenta_{i\downarrow}^{+} represent electron annihilation (creation) operators for i𝑖i-th single-particle eigenstate ψi​(𝒓)subscript𝜓𝑖𝒓\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{r}) which are assumed to be localized. Then operators Siαsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝛼S_{i}^{\alpha} introduced in (1) obey standard spin-1/2121/2 commutation relations. The Hilbert space spanned by the set of Siαsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝛼S_{i}^{\alpha} operators constitutes a part of the whole Hilbert space of the electron system; namely, we omit the states with some eigenstates ψi​(𝒓)subscript𝜓𝑖𝒓\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{r}) to be single-occupied. This is reasonable approximation as long as two-electron local binding energy ΔPsubscriptΔ𝑃\Delta_{P} is much larger than all energy/temperature scales relevant for the problem to be considered, see Ref. t2 .

The minimal Hamiltonian that describes development of superconducting correlations between localized electron pairs is of the form

H=−2∑iεiSiz−12∑i​jJi​j(Si+Sj−+h.c),H=-2\sum_{i}\varepsilon_{i}S_{i}^{z}-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{ij}J_{ij}(S_{i}^{+}S_{j}^{-}+h.c), (2)

where εisubscript𝜀𝑖\varepsilon_{i} are single-electron eigenvalues which are assumed to be distributed independently with the box distribution function P​(ε)=12​W​θ​(W−|ε|)𝑃𝜀12𝑊𝜃𝑊𝜀P(\varepsilon)=\frac{1}{2W}\theta(W-|\varepsilon|). The exact shape of the distribution function is important only for the Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} definition; as we will show below, the critical behavior near the transition (such as paraconductivity) depend only on the shape of the distribution function at ε≲|T−Tc|less-than-or-similar-to𝜀𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐\varepsilon\lesssim|T-T_{c}|. As long as density of states ν0=P​(0)subscript𝜈0𝑃0\nu_{0}=P(0) is finite, all the results will hold the same.

Matrix elements Ji​j≡J​(𝒓i−𝒓j)∝∫dd​r​ψi2​(𝒓)​ψj2​(𝒓)subscript𝐽𝑖𝑗𝐽subscript𝒓𝑖subscript𝒓𝑗proportional-tosuperscript𝑑𝑑𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖2𝒓superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑗2𝒓J_{ij}\equiv J(\boldsymbol{r}_{i}-\boldsymbol{r}_{j})\propto\int d^{d}r\psi_{i}^{2}(\boldsymbol{r})\psi_{j}^{2}(\boldsymbol{r}) actually depend in nontrivial way on the distance 𝒓=𝒓i−𝒓j𝒓subscript𝒓𝑖subscript𝒓𝑗\boldsymbol{r}=\boldsymbol{r}_{i}-\boldsymbol{r}_{j} as well as on the energy difference εi−εjsubscript𝜀𝑖subscript𝜀𝑗\varepsilon_{i}-\varepsilon_{j}; to simplify the problem, we employ below a model where Ji​jsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑗J_{ij} are assumed to have large radius R≫1much-greater-than𝑅1R\gg 1, and its Fourier transform takes the form J​(𝒑)=J​(1−p2​R2)𝐽𝒑𝐽1superscript𝑝2superscript𝑅2J(\boldsymbol{p})=J(1-p^{2}R^{2}) in the long-wavelength limit.

The disorder is assumed to be large, and the temperature is assumed to be small, so that W≫J≫Tmuch-greater-than𝑊𝐽much-greater-than𝑇W\gg J\gg T.

II.1 Mean field critical temperature and order parameter

The BCS order parameter, which is the anomalous average, corresponds to non-zero in-plane spin magnetization ⟨Six,y⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑥𝑦\left\langle S_{i}^{x,y}\right\rangle. The natural choice for the order parameter for the mean-field treatment is thus the following:

Φiα=∑jJi​j​⟨Sjα⟩,α=x,y,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptΦ𝑖𝛼subscript𝑗subscript𝐽𝑖𝑗delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗𝛼𝛼𝑥𝑦\Phi_{i}^{\alpha}=\sum_{j}J_{ij}\left\langle S_{j}^{\alpha}\right\rangle,\quad\alpha=x,y, (3)

while the ordinary superconducting complex order parameter takes the form Δ=Φx+i​ΦyΔsuperscriptΦ𝑥𝑖superscriptΦ𝑦\Delta=\Phi^{x}+i\Phi^{y}.

In the mean-field approximation one decouples spins living in effective magnetic field created collectively by other spins:

HM​F=−∑i,αhiα​σiα,subscript𝐻𝑀𝐹subscript𝑖𝛼superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝛼H_{MF}=-\sum_{i,\alpha}h_{i}^{\alpha}\sigma_{i}^{\alpha}, (4)

with Pauli matrix σiα=2​Siαsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝛼\sigma_{i}^{\alpha}=2S_{i}^{\alpha} and effective magnetic field 𝒉i=(Φix,Φiy,εi)subscript𝒉𝑖superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑖𝑦subscript𝜀𝑖\boldsymbol{h}_{i}=(\Phi_{i}^{x},\Phi_{i}^{y},\varepsilon_{i}). The Hamiltonian (4) yields trivial partition function for each spin Zi=2​cosh⁡(β​|hi|)subscript𝑍𝑖2𝛽subscriptℎ𝑖Z_{i}=2\cosh(\beta|h_{i}|). From this partition function we immediately extract the average magnetization ⟨Siα⟩=T2​∂ln⁡Zi∂hiαdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝛼𝑇2subscript𝑍𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝛼\left\langle S_{i}^{\alpha}\right\rangle=\frac{T}{2}\frac{\partial\ln Z_{i}}{\partial h_{i}^{\alpha}}, which yields following self-consistency equations:

∑jJi​j​ηj​Φjα=Φiα,ηj=tanh⁡β​εj2+Φj22​εj2+Φj2.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑗subscript𝐽𝑖𝑗subscript𝜂𝑗superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑗𝛼superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑖𝛼subscript𝜂𝑗𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜀𝑗2superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑗22superscriptsubscript𝜀𝑗2superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑗2\sum_{j}J_{ij}\eta_{j}\Phi_{j}^{\alpha}=\Phi_{i}^{\alpha},\quad\eta_{j}=\frac{\tanh\beta\sqrt{\varepsilon_{j}^{2}+\Phi_{j}^{2}}}{2\sqrt{\varepsilon_{j}^{2}+\Phi_{j}^{2}}}. (5)

Note that matrix Ji​j​ηjsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑗subscript𝜂𝑗J_{ij}\eta_{j} entering these equations is non-Hermitian; however, it can be made Hermitian trivially by rescaling Φi↦Φi/ηimaps-tosubscriptΦ𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖\Phi_{i}\mapsto\Phi_{i}/\sqrt{\eta_{i}} yielding a new matrix ηi​ηj​Ji​jsubscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜂𝑗subscript𝐽𝑖𝑗\sqrt{\eta_{i}\eta_{j}}J_{ij}. These equations acquire a non-trivial solution if the matrix has a unity eigenvalue. The critical temperature Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} can be defined as the highest temperature that is consistent with the same condition for 𝚽=0𝚽0\boldsymbol{\Phi}=0.

Under the assumption of a very large interaction radius R𝑅R, one can simply average all ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} over εisubscript𝜀𝑖\varepsilon_{i} and assume a homogeneous order parameter Φiα≡ΦαsuperscriptsubscriptΦ𝑖𝛼superscriptΦ𝛼\Phi_{i}^{\alpha}\equiv\Phi^{\alpha}. These simplifications lead to the self-consistency equation, which is nearly equivalent to the BCS one:

1=J2​∫𝑑ε​P​(ε)​tanh⁡(β​ε2+𝚽2)ε2+𝚽2.1𝐽2differential-d𝜀𝑃𝜀𝛽superscript𝜀2superscript𝚽2superscript𝜀2superscript𝚽21=\frac{J}{2}\int d\varepsilon P(\varepsilon)\frac{\tanh\left(\beta\sqrt{\varepsilon^{2}+\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{2}}\right)}{\sqrt{\varepsilon^{2}+\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{2}}}. (6)

For the box-shaped distribution P​(ε)𝑃𝜀P(\varepsilon), the critical temperature that follows from this equation reads:

Tc=4​eγπ​W​e−1/g,g=ν0​Jformulae-sequencesubscript𝑇𝑐4superscript𝑒𝛾𝜋𝑊superscript𝑒1𝑔𝑔subscript𝜈0𝐽T_{c}=\frac{4e^{\gamma}}{\pi}We^{-1/g},\quad g=\nu_{0}J (7)

Here γ≈0.577𝛾0.577\gamma\approx 0.577 is Euler’s constant. The parametric dependence Tc∼W​e−1/gsimilar-tosubscript𝑇𝑐𝑊superscript𝑒1𝑔T_{c}\sim We^{-1/g} is not sensitive to the exact shape of the distribution function, only the numerical prefactor is. Relevant parameters of the distribution function are: non-zero DoS ν0=P​(0)subscript𝜈0𝑃0\nu_{0}=P(0) and a typical width W𝑊W.

Note the absence of factor 2 in denomenator in the argument of tanh\tanh in Eq.(6); this is due to the absence of odd-electron states in the Hilbert space of our model. In result, the value of Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} is twice larger than in the BCS theory.

The value of the order parameter at T=0𝑇0T=0 is given exactly by the standard BCS formula

Φ​(0)=2​W​e−1/gΦ02𝑊superscript𝑒1𝑔\Phi(0)=2We^{-1/g} (8)

Eq.(6) is exactly valid in the limit of R→∞→𝑅R\to\infty only. For a finite R𝑅R, in order to find Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}, one should consider actual matrix Ji​j​ηi​ηjsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑗subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜂𝑗J_{ij}\sqrt{\eta_{i}\eta_{j}} for a given realization of {εi}subscript𝜀𝑖\{\varepsilon_{i}\} and look for T=β−1𝑇superscript𝛽1T=\beta^{-1} that corresponds to its highest eigenvalue equal to 1. Below we provide major results of the corresponding numerical analysis (the details are presented in the Appendix A).

Taking into account the large yet finite R𝑅R leads to the shift of the criterion for superconductivity from the value given by (7) to the larger temperatures. Typical behavior of the DoS at large R𝑅R obtained by means of numerical diagonalization and disorder averaging is shown on Fig. 9. The “main body” of the DoS fits reasonably well with the one predicted by the SCBA-approximation developed in the Appendix, and the width of the exponential tail is proportional to the Ginzburg number, Gi∼ρ2/(4−d)similar-toGisuperscript𝜌24𝑑\mathrm{Gi}\sim\rho^{2/(4-d)} with ρ𝜌\rho given by (38) and (39). Oscillatory behavior is an artifact caused by finite size of the system.

II.2 Semionic description and Keldysh diagram technique

In order to study the dynamical properties of the order parameter and develop a diagram technique, we choose the Fedotov-Popov representation for spin-1212\frac{1}{2} operatorsFedotovPopov ; Shtyk . Namely, for each spin we introduce a two-component spinor ψ=(ψ↑,ψ↓)𝜓subscript𝜓↑subscript𝜓↓\psi=(\psi_{\uparrow},\psi_{\downarrow}) describing a pair of fermions (called semions for the reason that will become clear soon), and represent spin operators in terms of semions (below σ^αsuperscript^𝜎𝛼\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha} is the set of Pauli matrices acting in the (↑,↓)↑↓({\uparrow},{\downarrow}) space):

Siα=12​ψi†​σ^α​ψi.subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛼𝑖12subscriptsuperscript𝜓†𝑖superscript^𝜎𝛼subscript𝜓𝑖S^{\alpha}_{i}=\frac{1}{2}\psi^{\dagger}_{i}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\psi_{i}. (9)

The physical subspace contains 2 states and corresponds to the presence of exactly one semion: ψα†​ψα=1subscriptsuperscript𝜓†𝛼subscript𝜓𝛼1\psi^{\dagger}_{\alpha}\psi_{\alpha}=1; in order to get rid of two extra (unphysical) degrees of freedom, one should introduce an imaginary chemical potential μ=−i2​π​T𝜇𝑖2𝜋𝑇\mu=-\frac{i}{2}\pi T for the semions FedotovPopov . In the imaginary-time Matsubara representation, such an addition to the chemical potential is equivalent to the additional phase shift equal to ±π/2plus-or-minus𝜋2\pm\pi/2 for fermionic fields translation over period along the imaginary time axis: ψα​(τ+β)=(±i)​ψα​(τ)subscript𝜓𝛼𝜏𝛽plus-or-minus𝑖subscript𝜓𝛼𝜏\psi_{\alpha}(\tau+\beta)=(\pm i)\psi_{\alpha}(\tau), thus these modified fermions were coined ”semions”.

The Hamiltonian (2) expressed in term of semionic degrees of freedom reads:

H=−∑iεi​ψi†​σ^z​ψi−14​∑i​j,α(ψi†​σ^α​ψi)​Ji​j​(ψj†​σ^α​ψj).𝐻subscript𝑖subscript𝜀𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖†superscript^𝜎𝑧subscript𝜓𝑖14subscript𝑖𝑗𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖†superscript^𝜎𝛼subscript𝜓𝑖subscript𝐽𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑗†superscript^𝜎𝛼subscript𝜓𝑗H=-\sum_{i}\varepsilon_{i}\psi_{i}^{\dagger}\hat{\sigma}^{z}\psi_{i}-\frac{1}{4}\sum_{ij,\alpha}(\psi_{i}^{\dagger}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\psi_{i})J_{ij}(\psi_{j}^{\dagger}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\psi_{j}). (10)

This expression for the Hamiltonian allows us to build a Keldysh diagram technique for calculation of spin-spin correlation functions. After decoupling the four semion interaction using the Hubbard-Stratanovich order parameter field ΦΦ\Phi (see Appendix B for the detailed derivation), we arrive at the following Keldysh action describing semionic as well as order parameter degrees of freedom:

and

where the shorthand notation Δ​(…)=(…)R−(…)AΔ…subscript…𝑅subscript…𝐴\Delta(\dots)=(\dots)_{R}-(\dots)_{A} is introduced. The only modification is that semions acquire an imaginary part in their distribution function, which is due to the imaginary chemical potential μ=−i​π​T/2𝜇𝑖𝜋𝑇2\mu=-i\pi T/2. That does not produce any problem since semions themselves do not correspond to any physical degrees of freedom, while original spins do.

Below we will use the developed diagram technique in order to calculate the order parameter correlation function L​(ω,𝒒)𝐿𝜔𝒒L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}) above the transition temperature, but in its close vicinity, where critical slowing down takes place.

II.3 Electric current

Anderson pseudospin operators Si±subscriptsuperscript𝑆plus-or-minus𝑖S^{\pm}_{i} create and annihilate pair of electrons on site i𝑖i. The electromagnetic gauge transformation thus acts as U​(1)𝑈1U(1) rotation on the spin operators Si±↦Si±​e±2​i​e​α​(𝒓i)maps-tosubscriptsuperscript𝑆plus-or-minus𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑆plus-or-minus𝑖superscript𝑒plus-or-minus2𝑖𝑒𝛼subscript𝒓𝑖S^{\pm}_{i}\mapsto S^{\pm}_{i}e^{\pm 2ie\alpha(\boldsymbol{r}_{i})} (with e𝑒e being electron charge, while speed of light is taken c=1𝑐1c=1). Accompanied by the gauge transformation for the vector potential 𝑨​(𝒓)↦𝑨​(𝒓)−∇αmaps-to𝑨𝒓𝑨𝒓∇𝛼\boldsymbol{A}(\boldsymbol{r})\mapsto\boldsymbol{A}(\boldsymbol{r})-\nabla\alpha this should leave the action (11) unchanged.

Real space enters problem via the J^=J​(p^=−i​∇)^𝐽𝐽^𝑝𝑖∇\hat{J}=J(\hat{p}=-i\nabla) matrix. The gauge field 𝑨𝑨\boldsymbol{A} thus enters the action by replacing momentum by the “covariant derivative” 𝑷^=𝒑^−2​e​𝑨​σ^y^𝑷^𝒑2𝑒𝑨superscript^𝜎𝑦\hat{\boldsymbol{P}}=\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}-2e\boldsymbol{A}\hat{\sigma}^{y}. The long-wavelength limit corresponds to J^−1≡J^−1​(𝑷^)≈J−1​(1+𝑷^2​R2)superscript^𝐽1superscript^𝐽1^𝑷superscript𝐽11superscript^𝑷2superscript𝑅2\hat{J}^{-1}\equiv\hat{J}^{-1}(\hat{\boldsymbol{P}})\approx J^{-1}(1+\hat{\boldsymbol{P}}^{2}R^{2}).

The electrical current induced by Cooper pairs can be extracted from the action using the following relation:

𝒋=δ​Sδ​𝑨=4​e​R2J​Φα​[σ^α​βy​𝒑^−2​e​𝑨​δα​β]​Φβ.𝒋𝛿𝑆𝛿𝑨4𝑒superscript𝑅2𝐽superscriptΦ𝛼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝑦𝛼𝛽^𝒑2𝑒𝑨subscript𝛿𝛼𝛽superscriptΦ𝛽\boldsymbol{j}=\frac{\delta S}{\delta\boldsymbol{A}}=\frac{4eR^{2}}{J}\Phi^{\alpha}\left[\hat{\sigma}^{y}_{\alpha\beta}\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}-2e\boldsymbol{A}\delta_{\alpha\beta}\right]\Phi^{\beta}. (16)

This relation holds on the classical field theory level, and it is translated to an operator identity of the corresponding quantum theory.

III Gaussian fluctuations and paraconductivity

In this Section we consider the fluctuation propagator of the order parameter L​(ω,𝒒)𝐿𝜔𝒒L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}) in the simplest Gaussian approximation, and calculate the corresponding fluctuation contribution to electric conductivity.

III.1 Order parameter propagator

On the Gaussian level, the order parameter Green function Lˇˇ𝐿\check{L} is given by the Dyson series shown on Fig. 2, with analytic expression given by

Lˇ−1=(Lˇ(0))−1−Sˇ,superscriptˇ𝐿1superscriptsuperscriptˇ𝐿01ˇ𝑆\check{L}^{-1}=(\check{L}^{(0)})^{-1}-\check{S}, (17)
Sμ​να​β​(ω)=i2​∫d​Ω2​π​Tr⁡(Γˇμ​σ^α​G^​(Ω+ω)​Γˇν​σ^β​G^​(Ω))superscriptsubscript𝑆𝜇𝜈𝛼𝛽𝜔𝑖2𝑑Ω2𝜋TrsubscriptˇΓ𝜇superscript^𝜎𝛼^𝐺Ω𝜔subscriptˇΓ𝜈superscript^𝜎𝛽^𝐺ΩS_{\mu\nu}^{\alpha\beta}(\omega)=\frac{i}{2}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}\operatorname{Tr}(\check{\Gamma}_{\mu}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\hat{G}(\Omega+\omega)\check{\Gamma}_{\nu}\hat{\sigma}^{\beta}\hat{G}(\Omega)) (18)

The expression for the self-energy part coincides with the unperturbed spin-spin correlation function Siα​β​(t−t′)=i​⟨σ^iα​(t)​σ^iβ​(t′)⟩subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛼𝛽𝑖𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑖delimited-⟨⟩subscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝛼𝑖𝑡subscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝛽𝑖superscript𝑡′S^{\alpha\beta}_{i}(t-t^{\prime})=i\left\langle\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}_{i}(t)\hat{\sigma}^{\beta}_{i}(t^{\prime})\right\rangle. Note that S^^𝑆\hat{S} is a diagonal in real-space matrix, which depends on the on-site random energy εisubscript𝜀𝑖\varepsilon_{i}. Since we are interested in ⟨L⟩εsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐿𝜀\left\langle L\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}, we need to average the whole Dyson series (Fig. 2). We employ an approximation of large radius R𝑅R which guarantees that propagator L𝐿L changes considerably on a long spatial scale which includes many individual ”spins” Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i}; thus we can build a kind of ”impurity diagram technique” with regard to random local fields εisubscript𝜀𝑖\varepsilon_{i}.

The Dyson equation for the average propagator ⟨Lˇ⟩delimited-⟨⟩ˇ𝐿\left\langle\check{L}\right\rangle reads

⟨Lˇ⟩ε−1=(Lˇ(0))−1−Πˇ.superscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ˇ𝐿𝜀1superscriptsuperscriptˇ𝐿01ˇΠ\left\langle\check{L}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}^{-1}=(\check{L}^{(0)})^{-1}-\check{\Pi}. (19)

To the leading order in large R𝑅R we can average all the Sˇisubscriptˇ𝑆𝑖\check{S}_{i} independently and put Πˇ≈⟨Sˇ⟩εˇΠsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ˇ𝑆𝜀\check{\Pi}\approx\left\langle\check{S}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}. Below in Sec. V we will take into account additional terms beyond this simplest approximation.

We now proceed with the calculation of the self-energy (18). The Keldysh space can be traced out immediately; the retarded (μ=q𝜇𝑞\mu=q, ν=c​l𝜈𝑐𝑙\nu=cl) component reads as follows:

SRα​β(ω)=i2∫d​Ω2​πTr(σ^αG^R(Ω+ω)σ^βG^K(Ω)++σ^αG^K(Ω+ω)σ^βG^A(Ω)).superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝛼𝛽𝜔𝑖2𝑑Ω2𝜋Trsuperscript^𝜎𝛼subscript^𝐺𝑅Ω𝜔superscript^𝜎𝛽subscript^𝐺𝐾Ωsuperscript^𝜎𝛼subscript^𝐺𝐾Ω𝜔superscript^𝜎𝛽subscript^𝐺𝐴ΩS_{R}^{\alpha\beta}(\omega)=\frac{i}{2}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}\operatorname{Tr}\Big{(}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\hat{G}_{R}(\Omega+\omega)\hat{\sigma}^{\beta}\hat{G}_{K}(\Omega)+\\ +\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\hat{G}_{K}(\Omega+\omega)\hat{\sigma}^{\beta}\hat{G}_{A}(\Omega)\Big{)}. (20)

We perform all the calculations by keeping γ𝛾\gamma finite, as we will refer to them later in Sec. IV.2; however, within Gaussian approximation for fluctuations the limit γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\to 0 is sufficient. The terms arising after substitution of semionic bare propagators given by Eq. (13) can be divided onto two groups. First group corresponds to semions residing on the same branch, ∝G↑​G↑proportional-toabsentsuperscript𝐺↑superscript𝐺↑\propto G^{\uparrow}G^{\uparrow} or ∝G↓​G↓proportional-toabsentsuperscript𝐺↓superscript𝐺↓\propto G^{\downarrow}G^{\downarrow}. The second group, where semions residing in different branches, can itself be naturally divided into diagonal and off-diagonal in spin space parts. Introducing the unit vector in the z𝑧z direction 𝒏=(0,0,1)𝒏001\boldsymbol{n}=(0,0,1), and performing the energy integration, we obtain following results:

and 𝔣​(ε)𝔣𝜀\mathfrak{f}(\varepsilon) is given by Eq. (15). In the limit γ→+0→𝛾0\gamma\to+0 these correlation functions describe trivial dynamics of a single spin precession in a constant magnetic field ε​𝒏𝜀𝒏\varepsilon\boldsymbol{n}.

Next step is to perform averaging over ε𝜀\varepsilon to calculate ΠR​(ω)≈⟨SR​(ω)⟩εsubscriptΠ𝑅𝜔subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑆𝑅𝜔𝜀\Pi_{R}(\omega)\approx\left\langle S_{R}(\omega)\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}. The off-diagonal part is odd in ε↦−εmaps-to𝜀𝜀\varepsilon\mapsto-\varepsilon even at finite γ𝛾\gamma and vanishes upon averaging, thus the only non-trivial contribution is due to SR(d​i​a​g)​(ω)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔𝜔S_{R}^{(diag)}(\omega). In the limit ω≪Tmuch-less-than𝜔𝑇\omega\ll T, it is natural to consider real and imaginary part of the correlation function independently. The real part is static, it determines the critical temperature of the transition, while the imaginary part is ω𝜔\omega-dependent and describes purely dissipative dynamics of the order parameter fluctuations:

⟨Re⁡SR(d​i​a​g)​(ω)⟩delimited-⟨⟩Resuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔𝜔\displaystyle\left\langle\operatorname{Re}S_{R}^{(diag)}(\omega)\right\rangle ≈⟨𝔣​(ε)ε⟩ε=1W​ln⁡4​eγ​Wπ​Tabsentsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝔣𝜀𝜀𝜀1𝑊4superscript𝑒𝛾𝑊𝜋𝑇\displaystyle\approx\left\langle\frac{\mathfrak{f}(\varepsilon)}{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}=\frac{1}{W}\ln\frac{4e^{\gamma}W}{\pi T} (24)

Note that the major contribution to the static part comes from logarithmically broad energy range between T≪ε≪Wmuch-less-than𝑇𝜀much-less-than𝑊T\ll\varepsilon\ll W, while the imaginary part is given by ε∼ωsimilar-to𝜀𝜔\varepsilon\sim\omega as it describes real resonant spin-flip processes which lead to the dissipation of the order parameter fluctuations. The presence of a linear in ω𝜔\omega term is thus a direct consequence of the non-zero single-spin density of states ν0=P​(ε≪T)subscript𝜈0𝑃much-less-than𝜀𝑇\nu_{0}=P(\varepsilon\ll T).

The above calculation leads to the following form of the order parameter propagator:

LR​(ω,𝒒)=1/2​ν0ϵ+q2​ξ02−i​ω​τ,subscript𝐿𝑅𝜔𝒒12subscript𝜈0italic-ϵsuperscript𝑞2superscriptsubscript𝜉02𝑖𝜔𝜏L_{R}(\omega,\boldsymbol{q})=\frac{1/2\nu_{0}}{\epsilon+q^{2}\xi_{0}^{2}-i\omega\tau}, (26)

with

ϵ=ln⁡TTc≈T−TcTc≪1,ξ0=Rg,τ=π4​T,formulae-sequenceitalic-ϵ𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐subscript𝑇𝑐much-less-than1formulae-sequencesubscript𝜉0𝑅𝑔𝜏𝜋4𝑇\epsilon=\ln\frac{T}{T_{c}}\approx\frac{T-T_{c}}{T_{c}}\ll 1,\quad\xi_{0}=\frac{R}{\sqrt{g}},\quad\tau=\frac{\pi}{4T}, (27)

and Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} given by the same expression as given above (7). The dimensionless parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon describes the distance to the superconducting transition, ξ0subscript𝜉0\xi_{0} corresponds to the “zero-temperature” coherence length, and τ−1superscript𝜏1\tau^{-1} defines the decay rate of the collective mode far from Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}. At small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, coherence length and relaxation time diverge as ξ​(ϵ)=ξ0/ϵ𝜉italic-ϵsubscript𝜉0italic-ϵ\xi(\epsilon)=\xi_{0}/\sqrt{\epsilon} and τ/ϵ𝜏italic-ϵ\tau/\epsilon, correspondingly.

We should emphasize that the form of the propagator (26) is independent of the exact shape of the distribution function provided it has non-zero DoS ν0=P​(ε=0)subscript𝜈0𝑃𝜀0\nu_{0}=P(\varepsilon=0) and does not change significantly at ε≲ωless-than-or-similar-to𝜀𝜔\varepsilon\lesssim\omega. The only parameter sensitive to the exact shape is Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}.

This form of the propagator is reminiscent of the ordinary time-dependent Ginzburg-Landau (TDGL)VarlamovLarkin theory describing the dynamics of the order parameter in the metals close to the superconducting transition. The difference is that in our theory ξ0subscript𝜉0\xi_{0} does not scale with Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} as it does in disordered metals, where ξ0∼D/Tcsimilar-tosubscript𝜉0𝐷subscript𝑇𝑐\xi_{0}\sim\sqrt{D/T_{c}}; another important difference is that the parameter τ𝜏\tau we found if twice larger compared to the value known for disordered metals, where τ=π/8​T𝜏𝜋8𝑇\tau=\pi/8T.

III.2 Fluctuational conductivity

We found in the previous Section that dynamics of our order parameter appears to be similar to the usual TDGL. Paraconductivity in superconductors above Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} was calculated long time ago by Aslamazov and Larkin AslamazovLarkin , while its calculation using TDGL formalism can be found in Ref. VarlamovLarkin . In this Section we briefly recapitulate the calculation and discuss the obtained results.

In order to obtain the expression for the electric conductivity of the system, one can apply Kubo formula,

σi​j​(ω,𝒒)=i​QRi​j​(ω,𝒒)−QRi​j​(0,𝒒)ω.superscript𝜎𝑖𝑗𝜔𝒒𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑅𝑖𝑗𝜔𝒒superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑅𝑖𝑗0𝒒𝜔\sigma^{ij}(\omega,\boldsymbol{q})=i\frac{Q_{R}^{ij}(\omega,\boldsymbol{q})-Q_{R}^{ij}(0,\boldsymbol{q})}{\omega}. (28)

where current-current correlation function in real space-time reads

Qμ​νi​j​(𝒓−𝒓′,t−t′)=−i​⟨jμi​(𝒓,t)​jνj​(𝒓′,t′)⟩,superscriptsubscript𝑄𝜇𝜈𝑖𝑗𝒓superscript𝒓′𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑖delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑗𝜇𝑖𝒓𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗𝜈𝑗superscript𝒓′superscript𝑡′Q_{\mu\nu}^{ij}(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime},t-t^{\prime})=-i\left\langle j_{\mu}^{i}(\boldsymbol{r},t)j_{\nu}^{j}(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime},t^{\prime})\right\rangle, (29)

and Eq.(28) contains its Fourier transform to (𝒒,ω)𝒒𝜔(\boldsymbol{q},\omega) representation.

Within the Gaussian approximation over fluctuations, the only diagram contributing to the Q𝑄Q-kernel is given by Fig. 3, and the corresponding expression yields (here p±=p±q2subscript𝑝plus-or-minusplus-or-minus𝑝𝑞2p_{\pm}=p\pm\frac{q}{2}, p=(Ω,𝒑)𝑝Ω𝒑p=(\Omega,\boldsymbol{p}) and q=(ω,𝒒)𝑞𝜔𝒒q=(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}):

QRi​j(ω,𝒒)=32iν02ξ02∫d​Ω2​πdd​𝒑(2​π)dpipj××(LR​(p+)​LK​(p−)+LK​(p+)​LA​(p−))superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑅𝑖𝑗𝜔𝒒32𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜈02superscriptsubscript𝜉02𝑑Ω2𝜋superscript𝑑𝑑𝒑superscript2𝜋𝑑superscript𝑝𝑖superscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝐿𝑅subscript𝑝subscript𝐿𝐾subscript𝑝subscript𝐿𝐾subscript𝑝subscript𝐿𝐴subscript𝑝Q_{R}^{ij}(\omega,\boldsymbol{q})=32i\nu_{0}^{2}\xi_{0}^{2}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}\frac{d^{d}\boldsymbol{p}}{(2\pi)^{d}}p^{i}p^{j}\times\\ \times\left(L_{R}(p_{+})L_{K}(p_{-})+L_{K}(p_{+})L_{A}(p_{-})\right) (30)

In the static limit ω→0→𝜔0\omega\to 0, the expression for the uniform (q=0𝑞0q=0) Aslamazov-Larkin conductivity is diagonal and reads σA​L=i​∂QR/∂ωsubscript𝜎𝐴𝐿𝑖subscript𝑄𝑅𝜔\sigma_{AL}=i\partial Q_{R}/\partial\omega, which can be further simplified:

σA​L=16d​ν02​ξ04​∫d​Ω2​π​dd​𝒑(2​π)d​𝒑2​𝔅′​(Ω)​(Δ​L​(Ω,𝒑))2subscript𝜎𝐴𝐿16𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜈02superscriptsubscript𝜉04𝑑Ω2𝜋superscript𝑑𝑑𝒑superscript2𝜋𝑑superscript𝒑2superscript𝔅′ΩsuperscriptΔ𝐿Ω𝒑2\sigma_{AL}=\frac{16}{d}\nu_{0}^{2}\xi_{0}^{4}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}\frac{d^{d}\boldsymbol{p}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\boldsymbol{p}^{2}\mathfrak{B}^{\prime}(\Omega)(\Delta L(\Omega,\boldsymbol{p}))^{2} (31)

Now we substitute Eq.(26) for the propagator L​(ω,𝒒)𝐿𝜔𝒒L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}), perform integration over energy using residues and switch to integration over dimensionless momentum P=p​ξ0/ϵ𝑃𝑝subscript𝜉0italic-ϵP=p\xi_{0}/\sqrt{\epsilon}, to arrive at:

σA​L=1ξ0d−2​ϵ2−d/2​8​T​τd​∫dd​𝑷(2​π)d​P2(1+P2)3≡σdξ0d−2​ϵ2−d/2,subscript𝜎𝐴𝐿1superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑2superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑑28𝑇𝜏𝑑superscript𝑑𝑑𝑷superscript2𝜋𝑑superscript𝑃2superscript1superscript𝑃23subscript𝜎𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑2superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑑2\sigma_{AL}=\frac{1}{\xi_{0}^{d-2}\epsilon^{2-d/2}}\frac{8T\tau}{d}\int\frac{d^{d}\boldsymbol{P}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\frac{P^{2}}{(1+P^{2})^{3}}\equiv\frac{\sigma_{d}}{\xi_{0}^{d-2}\epsilon^{2-d/2}}, (32)

where σ2=18subscript𝜎218\sigma_{2}=\frac{1}{8} and σ3=116subscript𝜎3116\sigma_{3}=\frac{1}{16}. Finally, we find paraconductivity in the form

σA​L={1/8​ϵ,(2​D)1/16​ξ0​ϵ,(3​D)subscript𝜎𝐴𝐿cases18italic-ϵ2𝐷116subscript𝜉0italic-ϵ3𝐷\sigma_{AL}=\begin{cases}1/8\epsilon,&(2D)\\ 1/16\xi_{0}\sqrt{\epsilon},&(3D)\end{cases} (33)

This result appears to be twice larger compared to the ordinary Aslamazov-Larkin resultAslamazovLarkin . The discrepancy can be traced back to the fact that τ𝜏\tau is twice larger compared to the ordinary metals, which we have briefly mentioned above. While in ordinary superconductors the AL paraconductivity provides a relatively small correction to the standard Drude conductivity σDsubscript𝜎𝐷\sigma_{D}, in our system with a large pseudogap, paraconductivity σA​Lsubscript𝜎𝐴𝐿\sigma_{AL} may occur to be the dominant contribution: the only alternative conduction channel is due to individual electrons hopping between localized states, those contribution is suppressed additionally due to Tc≪ΔPmuch-less-thansubscript𝑇𝑐subscriptΔ𝑃T_{c}\ll\Delta_{P} condition.

Below we will study different kinds of corrections to the Gaussian approximation we used, and show that Eq.(33) provides a very good approximation if ϵ≥ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1}, see Eqs. (38,39) below. Then we analyze corrections that appear at smaller values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

IV Local noise effect

Non-Gaussian effects due to interaction between fluctuating collective modes are generally known to become important for thermodynamics quantities in the close proximity of the critical point at ϵ≤Giitalic-ϵGi\epsilon\leq\mathrm{Gi}, where Ginzburg number Gi∼Z−2/(4−d)similar-toGisuperscript𝑍24𝑑\mathrm{Gi}\sim Z^{-2/(4-d)}. However, it was noticed in Ref. LO2001 , that for dynamics quantities (in particular, for paraconductivity) interaction corrections may become large in a parametrically broader range of reduced temperature ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. In the present Section we show that similar phenomenon comes about in our model as well. Namely, we find a rather special type of interaction corrections that affects the dependence of the relaxation time τG​Lsubscript𝜏𝐺𝐿\tau_{GL} on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, which become relevant already at ϵ≤ϵ1∼Gi1/ditalic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1similar-tosuperscriptGi1𝑑\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1}\sim\mathrm{Gi}^{1/d}, whereas all static quantities are still well-described within Gaussian approximation.

Specific kind of interaction corrections relevant at ϵ≤ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1} can be understood as a result of local ”back-action” of the order parameter (superconducting) fluctuations upon dynamics of individual ”pseudospins” Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i}. Indeed, Keldysh action (11) describes its dynamics under the fluctuating local “magnetic field” (Φix​(t),Φiy​(t),εi)subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑥𝑖𝑡subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑦𝑖𝑡subscript𝜀𝑖(\Phi^{x}_{i}(t),\Phi^{y}_{i}(t),\varepsilon_{i}). Since local correlation functions of the field 𝚽i​(t)subscript𝚽𝑖𝑡\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{i}(t) coincide with the propagator L​(ω,𝒓,𝒓′)𝐿𝜔𝒓superscript𝒓′L(\omega,\boldsymbol{r},\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}) calculated at 𝒓=𝒓′=𝒓i𝒓superscript𝒓′subscript𝒓𝑖\boldsymbol{r}=\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{r}_{i}, the action (11) together with Dyson equation (17) constitute a closed set of self-consistent equations. Solution of these equations would involve: i) finding dynamical correlation functions of a spin SisubscriptS𝑖\mathrm{S}_{i} under the action of dynamic ’magnetic field’ with a given correlation function of the local ”noise function” Ci​(t−t′)=⟨Φiα​(t)​Φiβ​(t′)⟩subscript𝐶𝑖𝑡superscript𝑡′delimited-⟨⟩subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝛼𝑖𝑡subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝛽𝑖superscript𝑡′C_{i}(t-t^{\prime})=\langle\Phi^{\alpha}_{i}(t)\Phi^{\beta}_{i}(t^{\prime})\rangle ; ii) calculation of the propagator L​(ω,𝒓,𝒓′)𝐿𝜔𝒓superscript𝒓′L(\omega,\boldsymbol{r},\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}) via Dyson equation; iii) self-consistent determination of the local noise function for each site i𝑖i. In general, the above scheme contains a macroscopic number of variables and thus it is untackleable. The problem can be grossly simplified if site-i𝑖i dependent noise function can be approximated by a single universal function: Ci​(t−t′)→C​(t−t′)→subscript𝐶𝑖𝑡superscript𝑡′𝐶𝑡superscript𝑡′C_{i}(t-t^{\prime})\to C(t-t^{\prime}). Below in Sec.V we will see that such an approximation is indeed valid in the range Gi≪ϵ≤ϵ1much-less-thanGiitalic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathrm{Gi}\ll\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1}. Currently we take it for granted and study the effect of such a transverse noise upon local spin-spin dynamics, order parameter dynamics and, eventually, upon paraconductivity.

The key characteristic of the noise is provided by the propagator at the coinciding points L​(ω,𝒓=𝒓′)𝐿𝜔𝒓superscript𝒓′L(\omega,\boldsymbol{r}=\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}). This quantity itself is ultraviolet divergent (with momentum integration should be cut off at Λ∼R−1similar-toΛsuperscript𝑅1\Lambda\sim R^{-1}), but relevant ω𝜔\omega and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-dependent part can be separated and is determined by the infrared behavior:

LR​(ω)≈18​π​ν0​ξ0d​{ln⁡(Λ2​ξ02)−ln⁡(ϵ−i​ω​τ),(2​D)Λ​ξ0−ϵ−i​ω​τ,(3​D).subscript𝐿𝑅𝜔18𝜋subscript𝜈0superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑casessuperscriptΛ2superscriptsubscript𝜉02italic-ϵ𝑖𝜔𝜏2𝐷Λsubscript𝜉0italic-ϵ𝑖𝜔𝜏3𝐷L_{R}(\omega)\approx\frac{1}{8\pi\nu_{0}\xi_{0}^{d}}\begin{cases}\ln(\Lambda^{2}\xi_{0}^{2})-\ln(\epsilon-i\omega\tau),&(2D)\\ \Lambda\xi_{0}-\sqrt{\epsilon-i\omega\tau},&(3D)\end{cases}. (34)

The “local noise” described by this propagator is small provided ξ0subscript𝜉0\xi_{0} is large enough.

IV.1 Spin relaxation and renormalization

The effect of the “noise” caused by the order parameter fluctuations on the spin correlation function can be studied perturbatively using the Keldysh action (11). There are, in general, two types of such a corrections: to a semionic propagator and to a vertex part, and we start from the first one.

The simplest diagram for the semionic propagator correction is shown on Fig. 4. Below we will focus only on the “↓↓\downarrow” semionic branch, as the expressions for “↑↑\uparrow” can be obtained simply by replacing ε→−ε→𝜀𝜀\varepsilon\to-\varepsilon. The corresponding analytic expression for the retarded component of the self-energy reads:

ΣR↓​(ω,ε)=−i2​∫d​Ω2​π​(GR↑​(Ω)​LK​(ω−Ω)+GK↑​(ω−Ω)​LR​(Ω))superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑅↓𝜔𝜀𝑖2𝑑Ω2𝜋superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑅↑Ωsubscript𝐿𝐾𝜔Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝐾↑𝜔Ωsubscript𝐿𝑅Ω\Sigma_{R}^{\downarrow}(\omega,\varepsilon)=-\frac{i}{2}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}(G_{R}^{\uparrow}(\Omega)L_{K}(\omega-\Omega)+G_{K}^{\uparrow}(\omega-\Omega)L_{R}(\Omega)) (35)

For ω≪Tmuch-less-than𝜔𝑇\omega\ll T one can neglect the second term proportional to semionic “distribution function” 𝔉​(ω)𝔉𝜔\mathfrak{F}(\omega), because the bosonic one is singular 𝔅​(ω)≈2​T/ω𝔅𝜔2𝑇𝜔\mathfrak{B}(\omega)\approx 2T/\omega. Under this assumption the self-energy part depends only on the simple combination of ω𝜔\omega and ε𝜀\varepsilon, namely ΣR↓,↑​(ω,ε)≡ΣR​(Ω=ω±ε)superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑅↓↑𝜔𝜀subscriptΣ𝑅Ωplus-or-minus𝜔𝜀\Sigma_{R}^{\downarrow,\uparrow}(\omega,\varepsilon)\equiv\Sigma_{R}(\Omega=\omega\pm\varepsilon) with

ΣR​(Ω)=T8​π​ν0​ξ0d​Ω​{ln⁡ϵ−i​Ω​τϵ,(2​D)ϵ−i​Ω​τ−ϵ,(3​D)subscriptΣ𝑅Ω𝑇8𝜋subscript𝜈0superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑Ωcasesitalic-ϵ𝑖Ω𝜏italic-ϵ2𝐷italic-ϵ𝑖Ω𝜏italic-ϵ3𝐷\Sigma_{R}(\Omega)=\frac{T}{8\pi\nu_{0}\xi_{0}^{d}\Omega}\begin{cases}\ln\frac{\epsilon-i\Omega\tau}{\epsilon},&(2D)\\ \sqrt{\epsilon-i\Omega\tau}-\sqrt{\epsilon},&(3D)\end{cases} (36)

Although semions do not correspond to real quasiparticles in the system, their properties nevertheless describe the physical spin correlation function. Namely, Im⁡ΣRImsubscriptΣ𝑅\operatorname{Im}\Sigma_{R} corresponds to the real processes of spin relaxation, and Re⁡ΣRResubscriptΣ𝑅\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R} describes renormalization of the spectrum. In the lowest order of perturbation theory, these two effects can be studied separately, and we start with the spin relaxation processes.

The spin flip rate γ𝛾\gamma, which enters the semionic Green function exactly as infinitesimal γ𝛾\gamma did in Eq. (13), is defined by the imaginary part of ΣRsubscriptΣ𝑅\Sigma_{R} taken on the “mass shell” ω=ε⇒Ω=2​ε𝜔𝜀⇒Ω2𝜀\omega=\varepsilon\Rightarrow\Omega=2\varepsilon:

γ​(ε)≈T8​π​ν0​ξ0d​1ε⋅{arctan⁡2​ε​τϵ,(2​D)Im⁡ϵ+2​i​ε​τ(3​D)𝛾𝜀⋅𝑇8𝜋subscript𝜈0superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑1𝜀cases2𝜀𝜏italic-ϵ2𝐷Imitalic-ϵ2𝑖𝜀𝜏3𝐷\gamma(\varepsilon)\approx\frac{T}{8\pi\nu_{0}\xi_{0}^{d}}\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\cdot\begin{cases}\arctan\frac{2\varepsilon\tau}{\epsilon},&(2D)\\ \operatorname{Im}\sqrt{\epsilon+2i\varepsilon\tau}&(3D)\end{cases} (37)

This rate was obtained on the perturbative level, and is valid only provided the rate is small compared to the spin coherent precession frequency, γ​(ε)≪εmuch-less-than𝛾𝜀𝜀\gamma(\varepsilon)\ll\varepsilon. This criterion clearly cannot be satisfied for all ε𝜀\varepsilon as γ​(ε→0)𝛾→𝜀0\gamma(\varepsilon\to 0) approaches constant value. A new energy scale ωcsubscript𝜔𝑐\omega_{c} emerges, that separates spins with mainly dissipative dynamics (ε≪ωcmuch-less-than𝜀subscript𝜔𝑐\varepsilon\ll\omega_{c}) from spins with coherent dynamics (ε≫ωcmuch-greater-than𝜀subscript𝜔𝑐\varepsilon\gg\omega_{c}). This effect can affect paraconductivity if the energy scale ωcsubscript𝜔𝑐\omega_{c} is large enough, namely, if ωc≫ϵ​Tmuch-greater-thansubscript𝜔𝑐italic-ϵ𝑇\omega_{c}\gg\epsilon T (note that ωcsubscript𝜔𝑐\omega_{c} itself can, in principle, depend on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon). The above criterion can be reformulated as a criterion for proximity to the transition ϵ≪ϵ1much-less-thanitalic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon\ll\epsilon_{1} with:

ϵ1=subscriptitalic-ϵ1absent\displaystyle\epsilon_{1}= ρ1/2,superscript𝜌12\displaystyle\rho^{1/2}, ρ𝜌\displaystyle\rho =116​ν0​ξ02​T=g​W8​R02​Tc,absent116subscript𝜈0superscriptsubscript𝜉02𝑇𝑔𝑊8superscriptsubscript𝑅02subscript𝑇𝑐\displaystyle=\frac{1}{16\nu_{0}\xi_{0}^{2}T}=\frac{gW}{8R_{0}^{2}T_{c}}, (2​D)2𝐷\displaystyle(2D) (38)
ϵ1=subscriptitalic-ϵ1absent\displaystyle\epsilon_{1}= ρ2/3,superscript𝜌23\displaystyle\rho^{2/3}, ρ𝜌\displaystyle\rho =116​π​ν0​ξ03​T=g3/2​W8​π​R03​Tc,absent116𝜋subscript𝜈0superscriptsubscript𝜉03𝑇superscript𝑔32𝑊8𝜋superscriptsubscript𝑅03subscript𝑇𝑐\displaystyle=\frac{1}{16\sqrt{\pi}\nu_{0}\xi_{0}^{3}T}=\frac{g^{3/2}W}{8\sqrt{\pi}R_{0}^{3}T_{c}}, (3​D)3𝐷\displaystyle(3D) (39)

The form of the expression for ωcsubscript𝜔𝑐\omega_{c} depends on the reduced temperature ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon:

ϵ≫much-greater-thanitalic-ϵabsent\displaystyle\epsilon\gg ϵ1::subscriptitalic-ϵ1absent\displaystyle\epsilon_{1}: ωc=subscript𝜔𝑐absent\displaystyle\omega_{c}= {T​ρ/ϵ(2​D)T​ρ​π/4​ϵ(3​D)cases𝑇𝜌italic-ϵ2𝐷𝑇𝜌𝜋4italic-ϵ3𝐷\displaystyle\begin{cases}T\rho/\epsilon&(2D)\\ T\rho\sqrt{\pi/4\epsilon}&(3D)\end{cases} (40)
ϵ≪much-less-thanitalic-ϵabsent\displaystyle\epsilon\ll ϵ1::subscriptitalic-ϵ1absent\displaystyle\epsilon_{1}: ωc=subscript𝜔𝑐absent\displaystyle\omega_{c}= {T​ρ1/2,(2​D)T​ρ2/3,(3​D)cases𝑇superscript𝜌122𝐷𝑇superscript𝜌233𝐷\displaystyle\begin{cases}T\rho^{1/2},&(2D)\\ T\rho^{2/3},&(3D)\end{cases} (41)

For the whole analysis to be consistent, we need the condition ρ≪1much-less-than𝜌1\rho\ll 1 to be fulfilled. Parameter ρ𝜌\rho is inversely proportional to the coordination number, ρ∼1/Zsimilar-to𝜌1𝑍\rho\sim 1/Z; note however extra numerical factor ∼0.1similar-toabsent0.1\sim 0.1 in the definition of ρ𝜌\rho, which makes non-Gaussian effects smaller than one could expect.

The real part of the self-energy Re⁡ΣRResubscriptΣ𝑅\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R} renormalizes the spectral weight of the spin correlation function Im⁡SRImsubscript𝑆𝑅\operatorname{Im}S_{R} in a following manner:

ImSR(d​i​a​g)(ω)=14∫d​Ω2​π(ΔG↓(Ω+ω)ΔG↑(Ω)+{↑↔↓})××(𝔉​(Ω)−𝔉​(Ω+ω))\operatorname{Im}S_{R}^{(diag)}(\omega)=\frac{1}{4}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}(\Delta G^{\downarrow}(\Omega+\omega)\Delta G^{\uparrow}(\Omega)+\{\uparrow\leftrightarrow\downarrow\})\times\\ \times(\mathfrak{F}(\Omega)-\mathfrak{F}(\Omega+\omega)) (42)

Since we are studying two effects from Im⁡ΣRImsubscriptΣ𝑅\operatorname{Im}\Sigma_{R} and Re⁡ΣRResubscriptΣ𝑅\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R} separately, it is sufficient to substitute Δ​G↑,↓​(ω)=−2​π​i​δ​(ω±ε−Re⁡ΣR​(ω∓ε))Δsuperscript𝐺↑↓𝜔2𝜋𝑖𝛿plus-or-minus𝜔𝜀ResubscriptΣ𝑅minus-or-plus𝜔𝜀\Delta G^{\uparrow,\downarrow}(\omega)=-2\pi i\delta(\omega\pm\varepsilon-\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R}(\omega\mp\varepsilon)); at low frequencies we arrive at

ImSR(d​i​a​g)(ω)=π​ω2​T[(1−ReΣR′(2ε))−1××δ(2ε−ω+ReΣR(2ε)−ReΣR(ω))+{ε↦−ε}]Imsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔𝜔𝜋𝜔2𝑇delimited-[]superscript1ResuperscriptsubscriptΣ𝑅′2𝜀1𝛿2𝜀𝜔ResubscriptΣ𝑅2𝜀ResubscriptΣ𝑅𝜔maps-to𝜀𝜀\operatorname{Im}S_{R}^{(diag)}(\omega)=\frac{\pi\omega}{2T}\Big{[}(1-\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R}^{\prime}(2\varepsilon))^{-1}\times\\ \times\delta(2\varepsilon-\omega+\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R}(2\varepsilon)-\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R}(\omega))+\{\varepsilon\mapsto-\varepsilon\}\Big{]} (43)

This spectral weight affects relaxation time of the order parameter τ𝜏\tau via the relation

ω​τ=12​ν0​⟨Im⁡SR(d​i​a​g)​(ω)⟩ε𝜔𝜏12subscript𝜈0subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩Imsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔𝜔𝜀\omega\tau=\frac{1}{2\nu_{0}}\left\langle\operatorname{Im}S_{R}^{(diag)}(\omega)\right\rangle_{\varepsilon} (44)

However, evaluation of Eq.(44) shows that the Gaussian value for the important parameter T​τ=π/4𝑇𝜏𝜋4T\tau=\pi/4 remains unchanged. We conclude that on the lowest order of perturbation theory, the effect coming from Re⁡ΣRResubscriptΣ𝑅\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R} does not affect the order parameter dynamics (and thus paraconductivity), and it is sufficient to focus on the spin relaxation processes only.

Finally, let us focus on the vertex-part corrections to the spin correlation function shown in Fig. 5; the corresponding analytic expression reads:

δSμ​να​β(ω)=−14∫d​ω12​πd​ω22​πLλ​ργ​δ(ω2)Tr(Γˇμσ^αG^(ω1)σ^γΓˇλ××G^(ω1−ω2)Γˇνσ^βG^(ω1−ω2−ω)σ^δΓˇρG^(ω1−ω)).𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑆𝜇𝜈𝛼𝛽𝜔14𝑑subscript𝜔12𝜋𝑑subscript𝜔22𝜋subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝛾𝛿𝜆𝜌subscript𝜔2TrsubscriptˇΓ𝜇superscript^𝜎𝛼^𝐺subscript𝜔1superscript^𝜎𝛾subscriptˇΓ𝜆^𝐺subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2subscriptˇΓ𝜈superscript^𝜎𝛽^𝐺subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2𝜔superscript^𝜎𝛿subscriptˇΓ𝜌^𝐺subscript𝜔1𝜔\delta S_{\mu\nu}^{\alpha\beta}(\omega)=-\frac{1}{4}\int\frac{d\omega_{1}}{2\pi}\frac{d\omega_{2}}{2\pi}L^{\gamma\delta}_{\lambda\rho}(\omega_{2})\operatorname{Tr}\Big{(}\check{\Gamma}_{\mu}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\hat{G}(\omega_{1})\hat{\sigma}^{\gamma}\check{\Gamma}_{\lambda}\times\\ \times\hat{G}(\omega_{1}-\omega_{2})\check{\Gamma}_{\nu}\hat{\sigma}^{\beta}\hat{G}(\omega_{1}-\omega_{2}-\omega)\hat{\sigma}^{\delta}\check{\Gamma}_{\rho}\hat{G}(\omega_{1}-\omega)\Big{)}. (45)

After working out the spin structure, one can see that two non-trivial contributions are proportional to Tr⁡(σ^α​ℙ^↑​σ^μ​ℙ^↓​σ^β​ℙ^↑​σ^μ​ℙ^↓)Trsuperscript^𝜎𝛼superscript^ℙ↑superscript^𝜎𝜇superscript^ℙ↓superscript^𝜎𝛽superscript^ℙ↑superscript^𝜎𝜇superscript^ℙ↓\operatorname{Tr}(\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\hat{\mathbb{P}}^{\uparrow}\hat{\sigma}^{\mu}\hat{\mathbb{P}}^{\downarrow}\hat{\sigma}^{\beta}\hat{\mathbb{P}}^{\uparrow}\hat{\sigma}^{\mu}\hat{\mathbb{P}}^{\downarrow}) (and the same with ↑⁣↔⁣↓↑↔↓\uparrow\leftrightarrow\downarrow); and after summation over μ=x,y𝜇𝑥𝑦\mu=x,y, these contributions exactly vanish. We conclude that lowest order non-trivial correction comes only from dressing semionic Green function in the loop, as it is shown in Fig. 4.

IV.2 Correction to the order parameter propagator

The semionic renormalization discussed above affects the spin correlation function, which enters the Dyson equation for the order parameter. The prime effect is upon the dissipative part of the order parameter propagator L​(ω,𝒒)𝐿𝜔𝒒L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}), which is determined by the spectral weight of the spin correlation function, see Eq.(44). The major contribution to the above average over local energies ε𝜀\varepsilon comes from ε∼ω≪Tsimilar-to𝜀𝜔much-less-than𝑇\varepsilon\sim\omega\ll T, thus the factor linear in ω𝜔\omega comes just from the expansion of the Fermi distribution function, 𝔣​(ω)≈β​ω𝔣𝜔𝛽𝜔\mathfrak{f}(\omega)\approx\beta\omega. This allows us to write the following formula for the important dimensionless parameter T​τ𝑇𝜏T\tau, which now can depend on frequency ω𝜔\omega (we remind that paraconductivity is proportional to it, and on the Gaussian level this parameter was π/4𝜋4\pi/4):

T​τ​(ω)=−14​ν0​∫d​Ω2​π​⟨Δ​G↓​(Ω+ω)​Δ​G↑​(Ω)⟩ε𝑇𝜏𝜔14subscript𝜈0𝑑Ω2𝜋subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩Δsuperscript𝐺↓Ω𝜔Δsuperscript𝐺↑Ω𝜀T\tau(\omega)=-\frac{1}{4\nu_{0}}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}\left\langle\Delta G^{\downarrow}(\Omega+\omega)\Delta G^{\uparrow}(\Omega)\right\rangle_{\varepsilon} (46)

In the previous section we have shown that real part of semionic self-energy Re⁡ΣRResubscriptΣ𝑅\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R} does not affect the product T​τ𝑇𝜏T\tau, while Im⁡ΣRImsubscriptΣ𝑅\operatorname{Im}\Sigma_{R} can be accounted for by the substitution of the propagators in the form (13) with nonzero γ𝛾\gamma, given by (37):

T​τ​(ω)=14​∫d​ε⋅γ​(ε)γ2​(ε)+(ε−ω/2)2𝑇𝜏𝜔14⋅𝑑𝜀𝛾𝜀superscript𝛾2𝜀superscript𝜀𝜔22T\tau(\omega)=\frac{1}{4}\int\frac{d\varepsilon\cdot\gamma(\varepsilon)}{\gamma^{2}(\varepsilon)+(\varepsilon-\omega/2)^{2}} (47)

Integration can be performed numerically, plots are shown on Fig. 6. Striking feature of all the curves is that they exhibit non-monotonous behavior. This analysis is consistent provided ω≥ωc𝜔subscript𝜔𝑐\omega\geq\omega_{c}, where the deviation of T​τ𝑇𝜏T\tau from π/4𝜋4\pi/4 is small.

At low frequencies ω≲ωcless-than-or-similar-to𝜔subscript𝜔𝑐\omega\lesssim\omega_{c} kinetic term in the propagator L​(ω,𝒒)𝐿𝜔𝒒L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}) is governed by the contribution coming from the spins with local fields ε≲ωcless-than-or-similar-to𝜀subscript𝜔𝑐\varepsilon\lesssim\omega_{c}, which obey nearly dissipative dynamics, which is difficult for analytical study. However, it is still possible to bring up some qualitative arguments that show that the product T​τ𝑇𝜏T\tau retains the same order of magnitude and can be modified by some numerical factor ∼1similar-toabsent1\sim 1 only. First we note that at ε≪ωcmuch-less-than𝜀subscript𝜔𝑐\varepsilon\ll\omega_{c} coherent contribution to spin dynamics is negligible (formally, we put here ε=0𝜀0\varepsilon=0) and the only energy scale that governs dynamics of these spins is given by ωcsubscript𝜔𝑐\omega_{c}. Symmetrized spin-spin correlation C​(t−t′)=⟨{S+​(t),S−​(t′)}⟩=φ​(ωc​|t−t′|)𝐶𝑡superscript𝑡′delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑆superscript𝑡′𝜑subscript𝜔𝑐𝑡superscript𝑡′C(t-t^{\prime})=\langle\{S^{+}(t),S^{-}(t^{\prime})\}\rangle=\varphi(\omega_{c}|t-t^{\prime}|) where function φ​(z)𝜑𝑧\varphi(z) decays fast at z≫1much-greater-than𝑧1z\gg 1, while φ​(0)=1𝜑01\varphi(0)=1. After transformation to the frequency domain, we find that Keldysh component of the spin correlation function is SK(d​i​a​g)​(ω)≃1ωc​φ~​(ωωc)similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝐾𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔𝜔1subscript𝜔𝑐~𝜑𝜔subscript𝜔𝑐S_{K}^{(diag)}(\omega)\simeq\frac{1}{\omega_{c}}\tilde{\varphi}(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{c}}), where φ~​(z)~𝜑𝑧\tilde{\varphi}(z) is some even function. Using now fluctuation-dissipation relation, one finds that Im⁡SR(d​i​a​g)​(ω)≃−ωωc​T​φ~​(ωωc)similar-to-or-equalsImsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔𝜔𝜔subscript𝜔𝑐𝑇~𝜑𝜔subscript𝜔𝑐\operatorname{Im}S_{R}^{(diag)}(\omega)\simeq-\frac{\omega}{\omega_{c}T}\tilde{\varphi}(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{c}}). This form can be used now together with Eq.(44), in order to estimate the product T​τ𝑇𝜏T\tau. Fraction of spins with small local energies εi≤ωcsubscript𝜀𝑖subscript𝜔𝑐\varepsilon_{i}\leq\omega_{c} is of the order of ∼ωc/Wsimilar-toabsentsubscript𝜔𝑐𝑊\sim\omega_{c}/W. Multiplying it with Im⁡SR(d​i​a​g)​(ω)Imsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔𝜔\operatorname{Im}S_{R}^{(diag)}(\omega) and using Eq.(44), we find that T​τ∼φ~​(0)∼1similar-to𝑇𝜏~𝜑0similar-to1T\tau\sim\tilde{\varphi}(0)\sim 1. This qualitative argument shows that the T​τ​(ω≪ωc)𝑇𝜏much-less-than𝜔subscript𝜔𝑐T\tau(\omega\ll\omega_{c}) is still a constant of the order of unity, which, however, may differ from the π/4𝜋4\pi/4.

IV.3 Effect on the paraconductivity

Let us now study the implication of the non-Gaussian effect discussed above upon the paraconductivity. We need to consider the corrections to the Q𝑄Q-kernel given by Fig. 3. In the leading order one should consider the same diagram, but with dressed order parameter Green functions, which we have studied in the previous Section.

As it can be seen from the calculation in Sec. III.2, the main contribution to the paraconductivity comes from the order parameter fluctuations with energies ω​τ∼ϵsimilar-to𝜔𝜏italic-ϵ\omega\tau\sim\epsilon and momenta p​ξ0∼ϵsimilar-to𝑝subscript𝜉0italic-ϵp\xi_{0}\sim\sqrt{\epsilon}. In the previous Section we have shown that the back-effect coming from the dynamics of ”noisy spins” changes the constant T​τ​(ω)𝑇𝜏𝜔T\tau(\omega) at frequencies ω≲ωcless-than-or-similar-to𝜔subscript𝜔𝑐\omega\lesssim\omega_{c} only. Thus we conclude, that this renormalization is negligible provided ωc≪ϵ​T=|T−Tc|much-less-thansubscript𝜔𝑐italic-ϵ𝑇𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐\omega_{c}\ll\epsilon T=|T-T_{c}|, which, in turn, leads to the applicability criterion for Eq. (33) in a form ϵ≥ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1} with ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} given by Eqs.(38,39).

At smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, the contribution of spins those dynamics is strongly affected by the noise, becomes dominant. However, as we saw in the previous Subsection, this effect can hardly change the kinetic coefficient τ𝜏\tau more substantially than by some factor of order unity; therefore we expect Aslamazov-Larkin-type paraconductivity, Eq.(33), to be valid qualitatively even at smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, down to ϵ≥ρitalic-ϵ𝜌\epsilon\geq\rho. Another types of corrections that come into play at still lower ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, will be considered in the next Section.

V Other types of fluctuational corrections

In the previous Section a special kind of a fluctuational correction was demonstrated, that becomes relevant for kinetic properties of our system in a relatively broad of reduced temperatures ϵ≤ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1}, where ϵ1∼ρ1/2similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ1superscript𝜌12\epsilon_{1}\sim\rho^{1/2} in 2D, and ϵ1∼ρ2/3similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ1superscript𝜌23\epsilon_{1}\sim\rho^{2/3} in 3D. On the other hand, standard Ginzburg criterion for the width of fluctuation-dominated region near second-order phase transition reads as ϵ≤ϵ2≡Gi∼Z−24−ditalic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ2Gisimilar-tosuperscript𝑍24𝑑\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{2}\equiv\mathrm{Gi}\sim Z^{-\frac{2}{4-d}}, where Z∼1/ρsimilar-to𝑍1𝜌Z\sim 1/\rho is an effective number of ”interacting neighbours”, see Eqs.(38,39). Thus we conclude that ϵ2∼ϵ1d≪ϵ1similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ1𝑑much-less-thansubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{2}\sim\epsilon_{1}^{d}\ll\epsilon_{1} for d=2,3𝑑23d=2,3.

Below in this Section we will consider some additional corrections to the Gaussian approximation of Sec.III, which are specific to the presence of strong disorder in our model; we will show that these effects also become relevant at ϵ≤ϵ2italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{2} only. Namely, we concentrate on the corrections to the approximation Πˇ=⟨Sˇ⟩εˇΠsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ˇ𝑆𝜀\check{\Pi}=\left\langle\check{S}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon} for the self-energy of the order parameter propagator L​(ω,𝒒)𝐿𝜔𝒒L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}), as defined by the Dyson equation (19).

In the calculation shown in the section III.1 we have studied the order parameter propagator averaged over the disorder by means of the Dyson equation (19), where in the leading approximation we used the self-energy Πˇ=⟨Sˇ⟩εˇΠsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ˇ𝑆𝜀\check{\Pi}=\left\langle\check{S}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}. The same approximation was employed in the calculation of all other quantities we have studied — including paraconductivity itself. In this Section we will study the deviations from the results of this approximation, using the semion diagram technique.

V.1 Corrections to L​(ω,𝒒)𝐿𝜔𝒒L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q})

Locator expansion for the propagator L​(ω,𝒒)𝐿𝜔𝒒L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}) averaged over distribution of {εi}subscript𝜀𝑖\{\varepsilon_{i}\} contains terms of the form Lˇ(0)​Sˇ​Lˇ(0)​Sˇ​…​Sˇ​Lˇ(0)superscriptˇ𝐿0ˇ𝑆superscriptˇ𝐿0ˇ𝑆…ˇ𝑆superscriptˇ𝐿0\check{L}^{(0)}\check{S}\check{L}^{(0)}\check{S}\dots\check{S}\check{L}^{(0)}. Previously we proceed with separate averaging of each Sˇˇ𝑆\check{S} term in this expansion. The first correction to this approximation contains simultaneous averaging of two locators Sˇˇ𝑆\check{S}, as shown in Fig.7; the corresponding analytical expression is ⟨SRα​μ​(ω1)​SRν​β​(ω2)⟩εsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛼𝜇𝑅subscript𝜔1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝜈𝛽subscript𝜔2𝜀\left\langle S^{\alpha\mu}_{R}(\omega_{1})S_{R}^{\nu\beta}(\omega_{2})\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}. We present calculation of such an object in the Appendix C, making use of Eqs.(21,22,23). ⟨(SR(d​i​a​g)​(0))2⟩ε≈14​ζ​(3)π2​W​Tsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔02𝜀14𝜁3superscript𝜋2𝑊𝑇\left\langle(S_{R}^{(diag)}(0))^{2}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}\approx\frac{14\zeta(3)}{\pi^{2}WT} (48)

The static (ω=0𝜔0\omega=0) contribution to δ​ΠR​(ω)𝛿subscriptΠ𝑅𝜔\delta\Pi_{R}(\omega) corresponds to the renormalization of Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}, which was already studied in the Appendix A (see Eq. 69 and comments below). The frequency-dependent part at ω​τ≪ϵmuch-less-than𝜔𝜏italic-ϵ\omega\tau\ll\epsilon contains a singularity at small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon:

δ​ΠR​(ω)−δ​ΠR​(0)≈−i​ω​τ4​π​T​ξ0d×{14​ζ​(3)π2​ϵ,(2​D)7​ζ​(3)π2​ϵ,(3​D)𝛿subscriptΠ𝑅𝜔𝛿subscriptΠ𝑅0𝑖𝜔𝜏4𝜋𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑cases14𝜁3superscript𝜋2italic-ϵ2𝐷7𝜁3superscript𝜋2italic-ϵ3𝐷\delta\Pi_{R}(\omega)-\delta\Pi_{R}(0)\approx-\frac{i\omega\tau}{4\pi T\xi_{0}^{d}}\times\begin{cases}\frac{14\zeta(3)}{\pi^{2}\epsilon},&(2D)\\ \frac{7\zeta(3)}{\pi^{2}\sqrt{\epsilon}},&(3D)\end{cases} (50)

which should be compared with the bare ω𝜔\omega-dependent term in L−1​(ω,𝒒)superscript𝐿1𝜔𝒒L^{-1}(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}), see Eq.(26). Then we find that the correction (50) is small provided

{ϵ≫WT​ξ02∼ρ,(2​D)ϵ≫(WT​ξ03)2∼ρ2,(3​D)casesmuch-greater-thanitalic-ϵ𝑊𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜉02similar-to𝜌2𝐷much-greater-thanitalic-ϵsuperscript𝑊𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜉032similar-tosuperscript𝜌23𝐷\begin{cases}\epsilon\gg\frac{W}{T\xi_{0}^{2}}\sim\rho,&(2D)\\ \epsilon\gg\left(\frac{W}{T\xi_{0}^{3}}\right)^{2}\sim\rho^{2},&(3D)\end{cases} (51)

which coincides with the usual Ginzburg criterion discussed in the beginning of this Section.

V.2 Spatial fluctuations of the conductivity

It was assumed implicitly during the calculation of paraconductivity in Sec.III.2 (and further discussion in Sec. IV C) that conductivity is uniform through the system and thus can be characterized as the kernel σ​(𝒓−𝒓′)𝜎𝒓superscript𝒓bold-′\sigma(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r^{\prime}}) in the linear relation between current density and electric field, 𝒋​(𝒓)=∫σ​(𝒓−𝒓′)​𝑬​(𝒓′)​d3​r′𝒋𝒓𝜎𝒓superscript𝒓bold-′𝑬superscript𝒓bold-′superscript𝑑3superscript𝑟′\boldsymbol{j}(\boldsymbol{r})=\int\sigma(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r^{\prime}})\boldsymbol{E}(\boldsymbol{r^{\prime}})d^{3}r^{\prime}. In the disordered medium, conductivity contains spatial fluctuations, so that the kernel becomes a function of two coordinates separately, σ​(𝒓−𝒓′)→σ​(𝒓,𝒓′)→𝜎𝒓superscript𝒓bold-′𝜎𝒓superscript𝒓bold-′\sigma(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r^{\prime}})\to\sigma(\boldsymbol{r},\boldsymbol{r^{\prime}}). In order to satisfy current conservation law, ∂αjα=0subscript𝛼subscript𝑗𝛼0\partial_{\alpha}j_{\alpha}=0, with the current given by jα​(𝒓)=∫σ​(𝒓,𝒓′)​Eα​(𝒓′)​𝑑𝒓′subscript𝑗𝛼𝒓𝜎𝒓superscript𝒓′subscript𝐸𝛼superscript𝒓′differential-dsuperscript𝒓′j_{\alpha}(\boldsymbol{r})=\int\sigma(\boldsymbol{r},\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime})E_{\alpha}(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime})d\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}, the local electric field Eαsubscript𝐸𝛼E_{\alpha} must fluctuate in space:

δ​Eα​(𝒓)=−1d​σ¯​E¯α​∫δ​σ​(𝒓,𝒓′)​𝑑𝒓′,𝛿subscript𝐸𝛼𝒓1𝑑¯𝜎subscript¯𝐸𝛼𝛿𝜎𝒓superscript𝒓′differential-dsuperscript𝒓′\delta E_{\alpha}(\boldsymbol{r})=-\frac{1}{d\overline{\sigma}}\overline{E}_{\alpha}\int\delta\sigma(\boldsymbol{r},\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime})d\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}, (52)

It results LandauLifshits in the additional contribution to the average conductivity of the form

δ​σ=−1d​K​(r=0)𝛿𝜎1𝑑𝐾r0\delta\sigma=-\frac{1}{d}K(\textbf{r}=0)

where correlation function K​(𝒓−𝒓′)𝐾𝒓superscript𝒓bold-′K(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r^{\prime}}) is defined as follows:

Below we will calculate this correlation function K​(𝒓−𝒓′)𝐾𝒓superscript𝒓bold-′K(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r^{\prime}}). The diagram of the lowest order is shown in Fig. 8. K​(𝒒)=56​ζ​(3)​Wπ2​σd2​T​ϵ2​ℱ2​(𝑸).𝐾𝒒56𝜁3𝑊superscript𝜋2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2𝑇superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptℱ2𝑸K(\boldsymbol{q})=\frac{56\zeta(3)W}{\pi^{2}\sigma_{d}^{2}T\epsilon^{2}}{\cal F}^{2}(\boldsymbol{Q}). (55)

K​(𝒓=0)=c​WT​ϵ2−d/2​ξ0d,𝐾𝒓0𝑐𝑊𝑇superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑑2superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑K(\boldsymbol{r}=0)=c\frac{W}{T\epsilon^{2-d/2}\xi_{0}^{d}}, (56)

with the prefactor c𝑐c, which can be obtained numerically:

c=56​ζ​(3)π2​σd2​∫dd​𝑸(2​π)d​ℱ2​(𝑸)={0.283,(2​D)0.099,(3​D)𝑐56𝜁3superscript𝜋2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2superscript𝑑𝑑𝑸superscript2𝜋𝑑superscriptℱ2𝑸cases0.2832𝐷0.0993𝐷c=\frac{56\zeta(3)}{\pi^{2}\sigma_{d}^{2}}\int\frac{d^{d}\boldsymbol{Q}}{(2\pi)^{d}}{\cal F}^{2}(\boldsymbol{Q})=\begin{cases}0.283,&(2D)\\ 0.099,&(3D)\end{cases} (57)

Now let us discuss the obtained result. The Aslamazov-Larkin formula (33) works only provided the correction K​(r=0)≪1much-less-than𝐾r01K(\textbf{r}=0)\ll 1. The result is essentially the same as the one obtained in the previous Section: the correction is small provided Eq. (51) holds.

VI Conclusions

We have shown in this paper that fluctuational conductivity effect, originally predicted by L.Aslamazov and A.Larkin 50 years ago, remains nearly the same in the case of strongly pseudo-gaped superconductors with just absent single-electron density of states. The role of single-electron states is taken over by the localized electron pairs, and the effect of that replacement reduces just to the factor of 2 change of the numerical coefficient σdsubscript𝜎𝑑\sigma_{d} in Eqs. (32,33) w.r.t. to the classical Aslamazov-Larkin result, while power-law dependence of paraconductivity on ϵ=ln⁡(T/Tc)italic-ϵ𝑇subscript𝑇𝑐\epsilon=\ln(T/T_{c}) remains the same. Our results were derived under the assumption that hopping of (initially) localized pairs occurs with a large effective ”coordination number” Z∼ρ−1similar-to𝑍superscript𝜌1Z\sim\rho^{-1}, see Eq.(38,39).

Universal character of the AL paraconductivity (especially, in 2D) makes it convenient experimental tool for determination of the critical temperature when R​(T)𝑅𝑇R(T) dependence is of considerable width, like it occurs in strongly disordered superconductors. For this reason, the issue of universality of the value of numerical coefficient σdsubscript𝜎𝑑\sigma_{d} is of interest. First, we note that it does not depend upon the shape of the local energy distribution function P​(ε)𝑃𝜀P(\varepsilon) as long as it is flat on the scale of very small ε∼Tcsimilar-to𝜀subscript𝑇𝑐\varepsilon\sim T_{c}. Some nontrivial structure at this energy scale in the effective distribution P​(ε)𝑃𝜀P(\varepsilon) may come about in the generalized model where long-range interaction of the type of Siz​U​(𝒓i−𝒓j)​Sjzsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑧𝑈subscript𝒓𝑖subscript𝒓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗𝑧S_{i}^{z}U(\boldsymbol{r}_{i}-\boldsymbol{r}_{j})S_{j}^{z} is included, that can be traced back to the Coulomb interaction between charges of localized pairs. The effect of such an interaction will be studied separately.

Since our condition of a very large pseudogap ΔP≫Tcmuch-greater-thansubscriptΔ𝑃subscript𝑇𝑐\Delta_{P}\gg T_{c} may be found too restrictive in applications, one might be interested in generalization of our result for moderate value of ΔP∼Tcsimilar-tosubscriptΔ𝑃subscript𝑇𝑐\Delta_{P}\sim T_{c}. That can be done in a rather straightforward way, once we note that the whole issue of the coefficient σdsubscript𝜎𝑑\sigma_{d} in Eq.(33) is controlled by the expansion of the effective spin distribution function 𝔣​(ω)=tanh⁡β​ω𝔣𝜔𝛽𝜔\mathfrak{f}(\omega)=\tanh\beta\omega over small ω𝜔\omega. In the standard TDGL theory VarlamovLarkin for disordered superconductors, the fermionic distribution function f​(ω)=tanh⁡β​ω2𝑓𝜔𝛽𝜔2f(\omega)=\tanh\frac{\beta\omega}{2} stays instead of 𝔣​(ω)𝔣𝜔\mathfrak{f}(\omega), thus making the coefficient in front of T​τ𝑇𝜏T\tau twice smaller than in our problem, see Eq.(27). For the general case of ΔP∼Tcsimilar-tosubscriptΔ𝑃subscript𝑇𝑐\Delta_{P}\sim T_{c} we can use an observation presented in the Appendix B to the paper t2 : for an arbitrary ΔP/TsubscriptΔ𝑃𝑇\Delta_{P}/T, a generalized distribution function is

𝔣​(ω,ΔP)=sinh⁡β​ωcosh⁡β​ω+e−ΔP/T𝔣𝜔subscriptΔ𝑃𝛽𝜔𝛽𝜔superscript𝑒subscriptΔ𝑃𝑇\mathfrak{f}(\omega,\Delta_{P})=\frac{\sinh\beta\omega}{\cosh\beta\omega+e^{-\Delta_{P}/T}}

which interpolate between tanh⁡β​ω2𝛽𝜔2\tanh\frac{\beta\omega}{2} and tanh⁡β​ω𝛽𝜔\tanh\beta\omega upon increase of ΔP/TsubscriptΔ𝑃𝑇\Delta_{P}/T. As a result, for a generic ΔPsubscriptΔ𝑃\Delta_{P} values, the enhancement factor in σdsubscript𝜎𝑑\sigma_{d}, w.r.t. to the standard AL result, is given by 2/(1+e−ΔP/Tc)21superscript𝑒subscriptΔ𝑃subscript𝑇𝑐2/(1+e^{-\Delta_{P}/T_{c}}), i.e. it quickly becomes close to 2 for moderate ΔP/T≥1.5subscriptΔ𝑃𝑇1.5\Delta_{P}/T\geq 1.5.

All the above discussion refers to the Gaussian fluctuation region, ϵ≥ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1}, see Eqs.(38),(39). At smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon non-linear corrections to the dynamics of the order parameter becomes important, they are discussed in Sec. IV. However, we present the arguments that power-law character of σA​L​(ϵ)subscript𝜎𝐴𝐿italic-ϵ\sigma_{AL}(\epsilon) dependence is not changed due to these ”local noise” effects, while the coefficient σdsubscript𝜎𝑑\sigma_{d} becomes somewhat different. Even more close to Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}, at ϵ≤ϵ2=Giitalic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ2Gi\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{2}=\mathrm{Gi}, all types of fluctuational corrections becomes relevant, which makes calculation of σA​L​(ϵ)subscript𝜎𝐴𝐿italic-ϵ\sigma_{AL}(\epsilon) difficult. Moreover, in this close proximity of Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}, conductivity becomes spatially inhomogenuous, as evidenced by Eq.(56).

Specific feature of fluctuational conductivity in superconductors close to SIT is that it may much exceed bare (unrelated to superconducting correlations) conductivity already in the region of ϵ≥ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1} where Gaussian approximation is valid. This is due to the absence in our case of the standard Drude contribution of the normal-metal type. Instead, Aslamazov-Larkin paraconductivity competes with hopping conductivity of individual electrons, that is further suppressed at T≪ΔPmuch-less-than𝑇subscriptΔ𝑃T\ll\Delta_{P}.

We are grateful to Lev Ioffe for useful discussions. This research was partially supported by the Russian Science Foundation grant # 14-42-00044, by the Basic research program of the HSE, and by the grant from the Basis Foundation (I.P.).

Appendix A Mean field approximation and finite R𝑅R effects on Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}

This Appendix is devoted to analytical and numerical study of the critical temperature Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} at the mean-field level. In Section II.1 we have formulated the following condition for the appearance of order parameter: the largest eigenvalue of the matrix Ji​j​ηi​ηjsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑗subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜂𝑗J_{ij}\sqrt{\eta_{i}\eta_{j}} should be larger than unity. with
