The shift of the spectrum edge leads to the renormalization of the coupling constant Jeff=J​(1+λG)subscript𝐽eff𝐽1subscript𝜆𝐺J_{\textrm{eff}}=J(1+\lambda_{G}) in expression for Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c}, Eq.(7), thus increasing the critical temperature slightly.

To support this calculation, we have performed numerical analysis of the spectrum of corresponding random matrix. The temperature T=β−1𝑇superscript𝛽1T=\beta^{-1} was taken close to the mean-field value of the critical temperature (7), so that spectrum edge is estimated to be close to unity. The Ji​jsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑗J_{ij} matrix was taken Gaussian, so that its Fourier transform has the form J​(𝒒)=J​exp⁡(−q2​R2)𝐽𝒒𝐽superscript𝑞2superscript𝑅2J(\boldsymbol{q})=J\exp(-q^{2}R^{2}); in that case the integration in Eq. (65) can be performed explicitly leaving the single algebraic equation for ΨΨ\Psi, which is then solved numerically to obtain the analytic fitting curve. The amount of disorder realization varied from ∼similar-to\sim30000 (for smallest system) to ∼similar-to\sim6000 for largest one.

The typical DoS pictures shown on Fig. 9 consists of the “main body” of the DoS, which is fitted by the SCBA formula reasonably well, and the exponential tail of localized states which always arise when one deals with random matrices. The oscillatory behavior is due to finite-size effects and momentum quantization in a system of finite size; they tend to increase upon increasing R𝑅R and decreasing L𝐿L. The superconductivity appears when the mobility edge separating localized and delocalized states crosses unity eigenvalue. Clearly, the edge of the spectrum is larger than unity, and the SCBA result, Eq. (68) gives the better estimation of the position of the edge as well as the whole curve.

The width of the tail ΓΓ\Gamma is known to be related to the Ginzburg number Gi∼ρ2/(4−d)∝R−2​d/(4−d)similar-toGisuperscript𝜌24𝑑proportional-tosuperscript𝑅2𝑑4𝑑\mathrm{Gi}\sim\rho^{2/(4-d)}\propto R^{-2d/(4-d)}. To support this claim, we performed numerical simulations for system with various R𝑅R and estimated the R𝑅R-dependency of the width of the tail. The beginning of the tail was determined by the intersection of the tangent line to the curve in the inflection point with the x𝑥x-axis, see Fig. 9. The best fit of the Γ​(R)Γ𝑅\Gamma(R) dependency is shown on Fig. 10, and corresponds to Γ​(R)∼R−2similar-toΓ𝑅superscript𝑅2\Gamma(R)\sim R^{-2}, which agrees with the prediction for d=2𝑑2d=2.

Appendix B Keldysh diagram technique for pseudospins

In this Appendix we will derive the Keldysh action and rules for diagram technique used to describe the pseudospin model (2) and its semionic representation (10) following Kiselev and Opperman KiselevOppermann . We introduce the standard Keldysh time contour C=(−∞,∞)∪(∞,−∞)𝐶C=(-\infty,\infty)\cup(\infty,-\infty) for the model and introduce the following action for the semions:

i​S​[ψ¯,ψ]=i​∫C𝑑t​(ψ¯​G^−1​ψ+14​(ψ¯​σ^α​ψ)​J^​(ψ¯​σ^α​ψ)),𝑖𝑆¯𝜓𝜓𝑖subscript𝐶differential-d𝑡¯𝜓superscript^𝐺1𝜓14¯𝜓superscript^𝜎𝛼𝜓^𝐽¯𝜓superscript^𝜎𝛼𝜓iS[\bar{\psi},\psi]=i\int_{C}dt\left(\bar{\psi}\hat{G}^{-1}\psi+\frac{1}{4}(\bar{\psi}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\psi)\hat{J}(\bar{\psi}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\psi)\right), (70)

where G^−1=i​∂t+εi​σzsuperscript^𝐺1𝑖subscript𝑡subscript𝜀𝑖superscript𝜎𝑧\hat{G}^{-1}=i\partial_{t}+\varepsilon_{i}\sigma^{z} is diagonal matrix in real space, and implied summation over coordinates. We introduce the two-component real Hubbard-Stratanovich field Φ=(Φx,Φy)ΦsuperscriptΦ𝑥superscriptΦ𝑦\Phi=(\Phi^{x},\Phi^{y}) with the following action:

i​S​[Φ]=−i​∫C𝑑t​Φα​J^−1​Φα,𝑖𝑆delimited-[]Φ𝑖subscript𝐶differential-d𝑡superscriptΦ𝛼superscript^𝐽1superscriptΦ𝛼iS[\Phi]=-i\int_{C}dt\Phi^{\alpha}\hat{J}^{-1}\Phi^{\alpha}, (71)

and perform a shift to decouple four-semion interaction Φα↦Φα−12​J^​ψ¯​σα​ψmaps-tosuperscriptΦ𝛼superscriptΦ𝛼12^𝐽¯𝜓superscript𝜎𝛼𝜓\Phi^{\alpha}\mapsto\Phi^{\alpha}-\frac{1}{2}\hat{J}\bar{\psi}\sigma^{\alpha}\psi, arriving at following action:

i​S​[ψ¯,ψ,Φ]=i​∫C𝑑t​(−Φα​J^−1​Φα+ψ¯​(G^−1+σ^α​Φα)​ψ).𝑖𝑆¯𝜓𝜓Φ𝑖subscript𝐶differential-d𝑡superscriptΦ𝛼superscript^𝐽1superscriptΦ𝛼¯𝜓superscript^𝐺1superscript^𝜎𝛼superscriptΦ𝛼𝜓iS[\bar{\psi},\psi,\Phi]=i\int_{C}dt\left(-\Phi^{\alpha}\hat{J}^{-1}\Phi^{\alpha}+\bar{\psi}(\hat{G}^{-1}+\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\Phi^{\alpha})\psi\right). (72)

This action effectively describes spins-1/2121/2 lying in a fluctuating magnetic field (Φix​(t),Φiy​(t),εi)superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑖𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑖𝑦𝑡subscript𝜀𝑖(\Phi_{i}^{x}(t),\Phi_{i}^{y}(t),\varepsilon_{i}), whose dynamics itself is coupled to the spins via the interaction vertex. This is thus a clear generalization of a simple static mean-field model described in Section II.1.

The next step is to separate fields lying on the upper and lower parts of the Keldysh contour as Φ=(Φ+,Φ−)ΦsubscriptΦsubscriptΦ\Phi=(\Phi_{+},\Phi_{-}) (and similarly for ψ𝜓\psi), and introduce a Keldysh rotation switching to “classical” and “quantum” bosonic fields: Φ′=(Φc​l,Φq)superscriptΦ′subscriptΦ𝑐𝑙subscriptΦ𝑞\Phi^{\prime}=(\Phi_{cl},\Phi_{q}); and their analog for fermions: ψ′=(ψ1,ψ2)Tsuperscript𝜓′superscriptsubscript𝜓1subscript𝜓2𝑇\psi^{\prime}=(\psi_{1},\psi_{2})^{T}, ψ¯′=(ψ¯1,ψ¯2)superscript¯𝜓′subscript¯𝜓1subscript¯𝜓2\bar{\psi}^{\prime}=(\bar{\psi}_{1},\bar{\psi}_{2}), via the following relations:

Φ=Oˇ​Φ′,ψ=Oˇ​ψ′,ψ¯=ψ¯′​Oˇ​τˇz,formulae-sequenceΦˇ𝑂superscriptΦ′formulae-sequence𝜓ˇ𝑂superscript𝜓′¯𝜓superscript¯𝜓′ˇ𝑂subscriptˇ𝜏𝑧\Phi=\check{O}\Phi^{\prime},\quad\psi=\check{O}\psi^{\prime},\quad\bar{\psi}=\bar{\psi}^{\prime}\check{O}\check{\tau}_{z}, (73)

with matrix Oˇ=(τˇx+τˇz)/2ˇ𝑂subscriptˇ𝜏𝑥subscriptˇ𝜏𝑧2\check{O}=(\check{\tau}_{x}+\check{\tau}_{z})/\sqrt{2} and τˇαsubscriptˇ𝜏𝛼\check{\tau}_{\alpha} being Pauli matrices acting in Keldysh space. This rotation yields following Keldysh structure of the propagators:

Lˇ=i​⟨Φ​ΦT⟩=(LKLRLA0),ˇ𝐿𝑖delimited-⟨⟩ΦsuperscriptΦ𝑇matrixsubscript𝐿𝐾subscript𝐿𝑅subscript𝐿𝐴0\check{L}=i\left\langle\Phi\Phi^{T}\right\rangle=\begin{pmatrix}L_{K}&L_{R}\\ L_{A}&0\end{pmatrix}, (74)
Gˇ=−i​⟨ψ​ψ¯⟩=(GRGK0GA).ˇ𝐺𝑖delimited-⟨⟩𝜓¯𝜓matrixsubscript𝐺𝑅subscript𝐺𝐾0subscript𝐺𝐴\check{G}=-i\left\langle\psi\bar{\psi}\right\rangle=\begin{pmatrix}G_{R}&G_{K}\\ 0&G_{A}\end{pmatrix}. (75)

Finally, the “rotated” action is given by Eq. (11). In principle, one can perform Gaussian integration over semionic degrees of freedom and obtain the effective action describing only the order parameter dynamics:

i​S​[Φ]=−i​∫𝑑t​Φα​J^−1​τˇx​Φα+Tr⁡ln⁡(G^−1+12​Γˇi​σ^α​Φiα).𝑖𝑆delimited-[]Φ𝑖differential-d𝑡superscriptΦ𝛼superscript^𝐽1subscriptˇ𝜏𝑥superscriptΦ𝛼Trsuperscript^𝐺112subscriptˇΓ𝑖superscript^𝜎𝛼superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑖𝛼iS[\Phi]=-i\int dt\Phi^{\alpha}\hat{J}^{-1}\check{\tau}_{x}\Phi^{\alpha}+\operatorname{Tr}\ln\left(\hat{G}^{-1}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\check{\Gamma}_{i}\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha}\Phi_{i}^{\alpha}\right). (76)

We remind that the order parameter fields Φ≡Φμα​(𝒓i)ΦsubscriptsuperscriptΦ𝛼𝜇subscript𝒓𝑖\Phi\equiv\Phi^{\alpha}_{\mu}(\boldsymbol{r}_{i}) has the following indices: “spin space” α∈(x,y)𝛼𝑥𝑦\alpha\in(x,y), Keldysh space μ∈(c​l,q)𝜇𝑐𝑙𝑞\mu\in(cl,q) and real space 𝒓isubscript𝒓𝑖\boldsymbol{r}_{i}; while the semionic fields ψ≡ψσ,μ​(𝒓i)𝜓subscript𝜓𝜎𝜇subscript𝒓𝑖\psi\equiv\psi_{\sigma,\mu}(\boldsymbol{r}_{i}) reside in “semionic pseudospin space” σ∈{↑,↓}𝜎↑↓\sigma\in\{\uparrow,\downarrow\}, Keldysh space μ∈{1,2}𝜇12\mu\in\{1,2\} and real space 𝒓isubscript𝒓𝑖\boldsymbol{r}_{i}.

Appendix C “Impurity” diagram technique

The aim of this appendix is to develop an “impurity”-like diagram technique which is used in Section V to study the deviations from the mean-field approximation presented in Section III due to the averaging over the distribution of {εi}subscript𝜀𝑖\{\varepsilon_{i}\}. The key element of the diagram technique that depended on the ε𝜀\varepsilon is the “crossed circle” presented on Fig. 2, which represents spin correlation function SRα​β​(ω)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝛼𝛽𝜔S_{R}^{\alpha\beta}(\omega). Upon averaging the e.g. Dyson series (17), the next non-trivial object arising is simultaneous averaging of two spin correlation functions corresponding to the single site ⟨SRα​μ​(ω1)​SRν​β​(ω2)⟩εsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛼𝜇𝑅subscript𝜔1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝜈𝛽subscript𝜔2𝜀\left\langle S^{\alpha\mu}_{R}(\omega_{1})S_{R}^{\nu\beta}(\omega_{2})\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}, which corresponds to the “impurity line” connecting two crossed circles in our diagram technique.

We proceed with the calculation of analytic expression for “impurity line” utilizing the spin structure (21) and expressions (22) and (23). The cross-term ⟨SR(d​i​a​g)​(ω1)​SR(o​f​f)​(ω2)⟩εsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜔1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑜𝑓𝑓subscript𝜔2𝜀\left\langle S_{R}^{(diag)}(\omega_{1})S_{R}^{(off)}(\omega_{2})\right\rangle_{\varepsilon} drops out due to its parity, while non-zero terms for ω1,2≪Tmuch-less-thansubscript𝜔12𝑇\omega_{1,2}\ll T yield:

⟨SR(o​f​f)​(ω1)​SR(o​f​f)​(ω2)⟩ε==ω1​ω24​⟨𝔣2​(ε)((ω1/2+i​0)2−ε2)​((ω2/2+i​0)2−ε2)⟩ε≈≈i​π4​W​T2​ω1​ω2ω1+ω2+i​0,subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑜𝑓𝑓subscript𝜔1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑅𝑜𝑓𝑓subscript𝜔2𝜀subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔24subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝔣2𝜀superscriptsubscript𝜔12𝑖02superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝜔22𝑖02superscript𝜀2𝜀𝑖𝜋4𝑊superscript𝑇2subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2𝑖0\left\langle S_{R}^{(off)}(\omega_{1})S_{R}^{(off)}(\omega_{2})\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}=\\ =\frac{\omega_{1}\omega_{2}}{4}\left\langle\frac{\mathfrak{f}^{2}(\varepsilon)}{((\omega_{1}/2+i0)^{2}-\varepsilon^{2})((\omega_{2}/2+i0)^{2}-\varepsilon^{2})}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}\approx\\ \approx\frac{i\pi}{4WT^{2}}\frac{\omega_{1}\omega_{2}}{\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}+i0}, (78)

Appendix D Calculation of conductivity correlation function

Here we briefly discuss the calculation of the conductivity fluctuations ⟨δ​σ​(𝒓,𝒙)​δ​σ​(𝒓′,𝒚)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝛿𝜎𝒓𝒙𝛿𝜎superscript𝒓′𝒚\left\langle\delta\sigma(\boldsymbol{r},\boldsymbol{x})\delta\sigma(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime},\boldsymbol{y})\right\rangle in the lowest order of perturbation theory given by the diagram shown on Fig. 8. The analytic expression for the loop integrals ℛi​jsuperscriptℛ𝑖𝑗{\cal R}^{ij} appearing in the Section V.2 reads as follows:

ℛi​j(ω,𝒒)=i8​ξ04W2∫d​Ω2​πdd​𝒑(2​π)dpip+j[𝔅(Ω−)LR(Ω+,𝒑+)(LR(Ω−,𝒑+)LR(Ω−,𝒑−)−LA(Ω−,𝒑+)LA(Ω−,𝒑−))++𝔅(Ω+)(LR(Ω+,𝒑+)−LA(Ω+,𝒑+))LA(Ω−,𝒑+)LA(Ω−,𝒑−))]{\cal R}^{ij}(\omega,\boldsymbol{q})=i\frac{8\xi_{0}^{4}}{W^{2}}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}\frac{d^{d}\boldsymbol{p}}{(2\pi)^{d}}p^{i}p_{+}^{j}\Bigg{[}\mathfrak{B}(\Omega_{-})L_{R}(\Omega_{+},\boldsymbol{p}_{+})(L_{R}(\Omega_{-},\boldsymbol{p}_{+})L_{R}(\Omega_{-},\boldsymbol{p}_{-})-L_{A}(\Omega_{-},\boldsymbol{p}_{+})L_{A}(\Omega_{-},\boldsymbol{p}_{-}))+\\ +\mathfrak{B}(\Omega_{+})(L_{R}(\Omega_{+},\boldsymbol{p}_{+})-L_{A}(\Omega_{+},\boldsymbol{p}_{+}))L_{A}(\Omega_{-},\boldsymbol{p}_{+})L_{A}(\Omega_{-},\boldsymbol{p}_{-}))\Bigg{]} (79)

In the low-frequency limit we take 𝔅​(Ω)≈2​T/Ω𝔅Ω2𝑇Ω\mathfrak{B}(\Omega)\approx 2T/\Omega, and perform integration over energy ΩΩ\Omega using residues, arriving at:

ℛi​j​(ω,𝒒)=16​W​T​ξ04​∫dd​𝒑(2​π)d​pi​p+j​ϵ+(𝒑2+𝒒2/4)​ξ02−i​ω​τ/4(ϵ+𝒑−2​ξ02)​(ϵ+𝒑+2​ξ02)​(ϵ+𝒑+2​ξ02−i​ω​τ/2)​(ϵ+(𝒑2+q2/4)​ξ02−i​ω​τ/2)superscriptℛ𝑖𝑗𝜔𝒒16𝑊𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜉04superscript𝑑𝑑𝒑superscript2𝜋𝑑superscript𝑝𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗italic-ϵsuperscript𝒑2superscript𝒒24superscriptsubscript𝜉02𝑖𝜔𝜏4italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝒑2superscriptsubscript𝜉02italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝒑2superscriptsubscript𝜉02italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝒑2superscriptsubscript𝜉02𝑖𝜔𝜏2italic-ϵsuperscript𝒑2superscript𝑞24superscriptsubscript𝜉02𝑖𝜔𝜏2{\cal R}^{ij}(\omega,\boldsymbol{q})=16WT\xi_{0}^{4}\int\frac{d^{d}\boldsymbol{p}}{(2\pi)^{d}}p^{i}p_{+}^{j}\frac{\epsilon+(\boldsymbol{p}^{2}+\boldsymbol{q}^{2}/4)\xi_{0}^{2}-i\omega\tau/4}{(\epsilon+\boldsymbol{p}_{-}^{2}\xi_{0}^{2})(\epsilon+\boldsymbol{p}_{+}^{2}\xi_{0}^{2})\left(\epsilon+\boldsymbol{p}_{+}^{2}\xi_{0}^{2}-i\omega\tau/2\right)\left(\epsilon+(\boldsymbol{p}^{2}+q^{2}/4)\xi_{0}^{2}-i\omega\tau/2\right)} (80)

This integral is taken at finite external momentum and thus it can have non-trivial tensor structure. We are interested in the diagonal conductivity, which is δ​σ=1d​σi​i𝛿𝜎1𝑑superscript𝜎𝑖𝑖\delta\sigma=\frac{1}{d}\sigma^{ii}. The next step is to make momentum integration dimensionless introducing 𝑷=𝒑​ξ0/ϵ𝑷𝒑subscript𝜉0italic-ϵ\boldsymbol{P}=\boldsymbol{p}\xi_{0}/\sqrt{\epsilon}, expand it in frequency, take trace ℛi​i/d≡ℛsuperscriptℛ𝑖𝑖𝑑ℛ{\cal R}^{ii}/d\equiv{\cal R} and introduce dimensionless function ℱ​(𝑸)ℱ𝑸{\cal F}(\boldsymbol{Q}):

i​∂ωℛ​(ω=0,𝑸)=−Wξ0d−2​ϵ3−d/2​πd​∫dd​𝑷(2​π)d​𝑷2+𝑷​𝑸/2(1+𝑷−2)​(1+𝑷+2)2​(11+P2+𝑸2/4+21+𝑷+2)≡−Wξ0d−2​ϵ3−d/2​ℱ​(𝑸)𝑖subscript𝜔ℛ𝜔0𝑸𝑊superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑2superscriptitalic-ϵ3𝑑2𝜋𝑑superscript𝑑𝑑𝑷superscript2𝜋𝑑superscript𝑷2𝑷𝑸21superscriptsubscript𝑷2superscript1superscriptsubscript𝑷2211superscript𝑃2superscript𝑸2421superscriptsubscript𝑷2𝑊superscriptsubscript𝜉0𝑑2superscriptitalic-ϵ3𝑑2ℱ𝑸i\partial_{\omega}{\cal R}(\omega=0,\boldsymbol{Q})=-\frac{W}{\xi_{0}^{d-2}\epsilon^{3-d/2}}\frac{\pi}{d}\int\frac{d^{d}\boldsymbol{P}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\frac{\boldsymbol{P}^{2}+\boldsymbol{P}\boldsymbol{Q}/2}{(1+\boldsymbol{P}_{-}^{2})(1+\boldsymbol{P}_{+}^{2})^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{1+P^{2}+\boldsymbol{Q}^{2}/4}+\frac{2}{1+\boldsymbol{P}_{+}^{2}}\right)\equiv-\frac{W}{\xi_{0}^{d-2}\epsilon^{3-d/2}}{\cal F}(\boldsymbol{Q}) (81)

We now switch to the calculation of this function in arbitrary spatial dimensionality.

2D case

Using substitution a=1+P2+Q2/4𝑎1superscript𝑃2superscript𝑄24a=1+P^{2}+Q^{2}/4, we perform angular averaging arriving at:

ℱ​(𝑸)=116​∫0∞P3​𝑑P​12​a4+Q2​(2​P2​Q2−5​a2)​(a+2​P2)a3​(a2−P2​Q2)5/2ℱ𝑸116superscriptsubscript0superscript𝑃3differential-d𝑃12superscript𝑎4superscript𝑄22superscript𝑃2superscript𝑄25superscript𝑎2𝑎2superscript𝑃2superscript𝑎3superscriptsuperscript𝑎2superscript𝑃2superscript𝑄252{\cal F}(\boldsymbol{Q})=\frac{1}{16}\int_{0}^{\infty}P^{3}dP\frac{12a^{4}+Q^{2}(2P^{2}Q^{2}-5a^{2})(a+2P^{2})}{a^{3}(a^{2}-P^{2}Q^{2})^{5/2}} (82)

Finally, we integrate over momentum; using substitution Q=2​sinh⁡θ𝑄2𝜃Q=2\sinh\theta, the integral yields:

ℱ​(Q=2​sinh⁡θ)=164​cosh2⁡θ​(1+3​2​θsinh⁡2​θ),ℱ𝑄2𝜃164superscript2𝜃132𝜃2𝜃{\cal F}(Q=2\sinh\theta)=\frac{1}{64\cosh^{2}\theta}\left(1+3\frac{2\theta}{\sinh 2\theta}\right), (83)

with the following asymptotic behavior:

ℱ​(Q)≈116⋅{1,Q≪11/Q2,Q≫1,(2​D)ℱ𝑄⋅116cases1much-less-than𝑄11superscript𝑄2much-greater-than𝑄12𝐷{\cal F}(Q)\approx\frac{1}{16}\cdot\begin{cases}1,&Q\ll 1\\ 1/Q^{2},&Q\gg 1\end{cases},\quad(2D) (84)

3D case

We use the same substitution a=1+P2+Q2/4𝑎1superscript𝑃2superscript𝑄24a=1+P^{2}+Q^{2}/4, and angular averaging yields:

ℱ(𝑸)=112​π∫0∞dPPa3[a+2​P2QarctanhP​Qa−−a​P​(a3−4​a2​P2+2​P4​Q2)(a2−P2​Q2)2].ℱ𝑸112𝜋superscriptsubscript0𝑑𝑃𝑃superscript𝑎3delimited-[]𝑎2superscript𝑃2𝑄arctanh𝑃𝑄𝑎𝑎𝑃superscript𝑎34superscript𝑎2superscript𝑃22superscript𝑃4superscript𝑄2superscriptsuperscript𝑎2superscript𝑃2superscript𝑄22{\cal F}(\boldsymbol{Q})=\frac{1}{12\pi}\int_{0}^{\infty}dP\frac{P}{a^{3}}\Big{[}\frac{a+2P^{2}}{Q}{\rm arctanh}\frac{PQ}{a}-\\ -\frac{aP(a^{3}-4a^{2}P^{2}+2P^{4}Q^{2})}{(a^{2}-P^{2}Q^{2})^{2}}\Big{]}. (85)

Again, using the same substitution Q=2​sinh⁡θ𝑄2𝜃Q=2\sinh\theta, the integral yields:

ℱ​(Q=2​sinh⁡θ)=1192​cosh2⁡θ​(2+1cosh2⁡(θ/2)),ℱ𝑄2𝜃1192superscript2𝜃21superscript2𝜃2{\cal F}(Q=2\sinh\theta)=\frac{1}{192\cosh^{2}\theta}\left(2+\frac{1}{\cosh^{2}(\theta/2)}\right), (86)

with the following asymptotic behavior:

ℱ​(Q)≈1192⋅{3,Q≪18/Q2,Q≫1,(3​D)ℱ𝑄⋅1192cases3much-less-than𝑄18superscript𝑄2much-greater-than𝑄13𝐷{\cal F}(Q)\approx\frac{1}{192}\cdot\begin{cases}3,&Q\ll 1\\ 8/Q^{2},&Q\gg 1\end{cases},\quad(3D) (87)
